 CT,CORONAL,SAGITAL,OBL RECONSTRUCTION
 Reason: SUDDEN RESPIRATORY FAILURE PAT INTUBATED
 Field of view: 38 Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 100
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 3**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  51 year old obese woman with sudden respiratory failure post-op knee surgery on
  [**6-27**] now transferred from outside hospital intubated with continued oxygen
  requirement.
  Thanks
  [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 28727**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 81450**]
  [**Numeric Identifier 44092**]
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Please evaluate for pulmonary embolus
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  SUDDEN RESPIRATORY FAILURE POSTOP KNEE SURGERY.  TRANSFERRED FROM
 OUTSIDE HOSPITAL.  INTUBATED WITH CONTINUED OXYGEN REQUIREMENT.  EVALUATION
 FOR PULMONARY EMBOLUS.

 TECHNIQUE:  A CT angiogram of the pulmonary arteries was obtained following a
 rapid bolus of IV contrast.

 CONTRAST:  100 cc Optiray for a rapid bolus per CT angiogram protocol.

 CT ANGIOGRAM:

 No pulmonary embolism is identified.

 MULTIPLANAR REFORMATIONS:  Images demonstrate findings as described above.

 CT CHEST WITH CONTRAST:

 The tip of an endotracheal tube is in the right main bronchus.  The tip of a
 nasogastric tube is in the stomach.  There is a right central venous catheter
 extending to the cavoatrial junction.  Complete collapse of the lung with air
 bronchograms is demonstrated.  There is only a minimal amount of left pleural
 fluid.  In the right lung, there is extensive ground-glass opacity with more
 focal areas of airspace disease, particularly at the right lung base. There is
 no pericardial effusion.

 There are no suspicious osseous lesions.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Tip of endotracheal tube in right main bronchus with complete collapse of
 the left lung.

 2.  No pulmonary embolism.

 3.  Extensive ground-glass opacity in the right lung with more focal areas of
 airspace disease.

                                                             (Over)

[**2152-3-16**] 8:50 AM
 CHEST (PORTABLE AP)                                             Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 25209**]
 Reason: ASSESS LINE PLACEMENT, OG PLACEMENT, ETT TUBE PLACEMENT, CHF
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 4**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  73 year old woman with S/P CARDIAC ARREST AND MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION NOW WITH
  IABP, OG TUBE AND ETT
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  ASSESS LINE PLACEMENT, OG PLACEMENT, ETT TUBE PLACEMENT, CHF
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION: 73 y/o woman s/p cardiac arrest. Assess lines and tubes placement
 as well as for CHF.

 A single portable supine chest radiograph was obtained. There are no prior
 studies available for comparison.

 The ETT is identified approximately 1-2 cm above the carina. There is an NG
 tube with its tip in the fundus of the stomach. An intra-aortic balloon pump
 is seen with its tip approximately 2 cm below the aortic arch.

 The overall heart size is enlarged with left ventricular predominance. The
 aorta appears calcified and unfolded. There is a diffuse combined interstitial
 and alveolar pattern of opacity consistent with pulmonary edema, presumably
 cardiogenic in origin. There is a probable small left pleural effusion. No
 areas of consolidation are identified.

 IMPRESSION: Positioning of lines and tubes as described above. The IABP is
 appropriately positioned and the ETT could be withdrawn by approximately 2 cm.
 2) Diffuse interstitial and alveolar opacities likely representing moderate
 left heart failure.

[**2141-3-23**] 3:38 PM
 PIC CHECK/REPO                                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 2147**]
 Reason: THYMOGLOBULIN TO PREVENT TRASPLANT REJECTION
 ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
 * [**Numeric Identifier 58**] CVL/PICC                        [**Numeric Identifier 22**] UD GUID FOR NEEDLE PLACMENT      *
 * [**Numeric Identifier 59**] CHEST AP ONLY                                                          *
 ****************************************************************************
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY: End stage renal disease with poor IV access. PICC line was attempted
 at bedside and was unsuccessful.

 RADIOLOGISTS PERFORMING PROCEDURE: This procedure was performed by Drs. [**First Name (STitle) **]
 and [**Name5 (PTitle) 2148**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2148**], the staff radiologist, was present throughout the
 entire procedure and supervised the procedure Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 135**] reviewed the case..

 PROCEDURE/TECHNIQUE:
 After the nature of the procedure, risks and benefits of doing/not doing the
 procedure and alternatives to the procedure were explained to the patient, he
 was given the opportunity to ask questions. Subsequently, informed consent was
 obtained.  Later, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and placed
 in supine position with the left arm abducted.  The left arm was prepped and
 draped in usual sterile fashion.  Because no superficial vessels were visible,
 ultrasonographic evaluation was performed.  Ultrasound demonstrated patent and
 compressible parabrachial veins.

 Under real-time ultrasonographic guidance a 21 gauge needle was introduced
 into the left brachial vein via an anesthetized skin site.  An 018 guidewire
 was passed retrograde under fluoroscopic guidance and the needle was exchanged
 for a 5 french dilator sheath.  The wire was then exchanged for the 018
 measuring guidewire, which was positioned into the superior vena cava and the
 inner dilator was exchanged for the appropriately trimmed 38 cm long 5 french
 single lumen Vaxcel brand PICC, which was positioned into the superior vena
 cava under fluruoscopic guidance.  The sheath was removed.  Good bidirectional
 flow was obtained and the catheter was flushed, capped and bandaged in place.
 A post procedural chest radiograph was obtained in order to document
 positioning.

 CONTRAST/MEDICATIONS: No contrast or medications were used for this
 examination.

 FINDINGS:
 1) Technically successful placement of a 38 cm, 5 french, single lumen Vaxcel
 brand PICC into the superior vena cava via the left medial brachial vein.

 COMPLICATIONS: There were no immediate complications.  The patient tolerated
 the procedure well and left the department in good condition.

 IMPRESSION:
 1) Technically successful placement of a 5 french, 38 cm long, single lumen
 Vaxcel brand PICC into the superior vena cava via the left medial brachial
 vein.
                                                             (Over)

PERSANTINE MIBI                                                 Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 24218**]
 Reason: CAD, S/P LAD.  EVALUATE FOR REGIONAL ISCHEMIA.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 SUMMARY OF EXERCISE DATA FROM THE REPORT OF THE EXERCISE LAB:
 Persantine was infused intravenously for approximately 4 minutes at a  dose of
 approximately 0.142 mg/kg/min.  No anginal type symptoms or ECG changes from
 baseline were noted.

 HISTORY:  H/o 3-vessel disease, s/p anterolateral wall myocardial infarction,
 LAD stenting and PTCA of D1, referred for CAD evaluation.

 INTERPRETATION:  One to three minutes after the cessation of infusion,
 MIBI was administered IV.

 Image Protocol: Gated SPECT.

 Resting perfusion images were obtained with thallium.
 Tracer was injected 15 minutes prior to obtaining the resting images.

 Stress images show a severe perfusion defect in the anterior wall extending to
 the apex, which is predominantly fixed when correlated with the resting
 perfusion images.

 Ejection fraction calculated from gated wall motion images obtained after
 Persantine administration shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of
 approximately 49%.  Akinesis in the region of the perfusion defect in the
 anterior wall and apex is demonstrated.

 Note is also made of a vague, ill-defined area of increased tracer activity in
 the right chest, which may represent increased soft tissue uptake.  Recommend
 clinical correlation to rule out mass lesion.

 IMPRESSION:  1) Severe, predominantly fixed perfusion defect in the anterior
 wall extending into the apex, with associated akinesis in this region and mildly
 decreased ejection fraction.  2) A vague, ill-defined area of increased tracer
 activity in the right chest, which may represent increased soft tissue uptake,
 recommend clinical correlation to rule out  mass lesion. /nkg

 EXAMINATION:  Abdominal aortogram and right leg runoff [**2114-9-28**].

 HISTORY:  77 year old male with right foot ulceration and right lower
 extremity rest pain.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 512**] and [**Doctor Last Name 2148**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2148**] (the Attending
 Radiologist) was present and supervised the entire procedure.

 TECHNIQUE:  The procedure was explained to the patient and informed consent
 was obtained.  Since the patient could not tolerate lying flat for any length
 of time secondary to severe discomfort, the decision was made to use a left
 brachial artery approach.  Anesthesia was also consulted for MAC.

 The left arm was draped and prepped in the usual sterile manner, and using
 ultrasound guidance, the left brachial artery was accessed using a
 micropuncture needle.  A 0.018 guide wire was subsequently advanced into the
 left subclavian artery, and the needle was exchanged for a 4-French dilator.
 The 0.018 guide wire was then removed and an 0.035 [**Last Name (un) 414**] guide wire was
 advanced into the abdominal aorta under fluoroscopic guidance.  The dilator
 was then exchanged for a 4-French sheath over the guide wire.  A 4-French Omni
 Flush catheter was then advanced over the guide wire, and under fluoroscopic
 guidance, the tip was positioned in the proximal abdominal aorta.  An AP
 abdominal aortogram was performed.

 Under fluoroscopic guidance, the tip of the catheter was then repositioned
 just proximal to the iliac bifurcation.  A pelvic angiogram was performed in
 the left anterior oblique projection.

 The catheter was then exchanged for a 4-French Berenstein catheter over a
 0.035 guide wire.  The guide wire was then exchanged for a stiff Glidewire,
 which was advanced into the right common iliac artery.  Under fluoroscopic
 guidance, the guide wire was advanced into the right superficial femoral
 artery, however, the catheter could not be advanced over the wire.  The wire
 was therefore exchanged for a 0.035 Super Stiff Amplatz, which was advanced
 into the right superficial femoral artery and positioned there for stability.
 The Berenstein catheter was advanced over the guide wire, and the tip
 positioned in the right external iliac artery, under fluoroscopic guidance.
                                                             (Over)

 [**2114-9-28**] 1:42 PM

 Reason: ?? pvd  better define distal arterial anatomy
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 295
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 The guide wire was then removed and a right leg runoff was performed.

 "Pull-back" pressures were then obtained between the right external iliac
 artery, right common iliac artery, and distal abdominal aorta.

 The catheter and sheath were then removed, and manual compression applied to
 the left arm access site, until hemostasis was achieved.

 The patient received a total of 300 cc of non-ionic contrast secondary to his
 history of significant cardiovascular disease.

 The patient also received half an inch of nitro paste to the anterior chest
 wall for arterial spasm.  During the right leg runoff, he also received 100
 mcg of nitroglycerin intraarterially for arterial spasm.

 FINDINGS:  AP aortogram demonstrated a tortuous abdominal aorta without
 significant atherosclerotic disease.  Bilateral patent renal arteries and
 bilateral symmetric nephrograms were demonstrated.

 Pelvic angiogram demonstrated bilateral very tortuous iliac arteries, without
 significant atherosclerotic disease.  The internal iliac arteries were also
 patent and unremarkable.

 Right leg runoff demonstrated patent right common femoral artery and
 superficial femoral artery without significant atherosclerotic disease.  Mild-
 to-moderate atherosclerotic disease was present in the popliteal artery, but
 without significant stenoses.  Below the knee, there is occlusion of the
 proximal anterior tibial and posterior tibial arteries.  The right peroneal
 artery is the only runoff to the lower leg, and demonstrates diffuse
 moderately- severe atherosclerotic disease throughout its course.  At the
 ankle, the peroneal artery reconstitutes the distal posterior tibial artery
 which supplies the plantar branches.  The peroneal artery also reconstitutes
 the dorsalis pedis artery, which is contiguous with the pedal arch.  Both
 reconstituted posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries are of good
 caliber, and without significant atherosclerotic disease.

 No hemodynamically significant pressure gradient was measured between the
 right external iliac artery, right common iliac artery, and distal abdominal
 aorta.

 The patient tolerated the procedure without complication.

 IMPRESSION:  Tortuous but unremarkable abdominal aorta and iliac arteries.
 Patent right common femoral, superficial femoral and popliteal arteries.
 Occlusion of the proximal right anterior tibial and posterior tibial arteries.
  Right peroneal artery only runoff to the right leg, with diffuse
                                                             (Over)

 INDICATION: A 51-year-old woman s/p knee surgery, now with ARDS and intubated.
 Needs PICC line placement for IV antibiotics.

 RADIOLOGISTS PERFORMING THE PROCEDURE: Drs. [**First Name (STitle) 27**] [**Name (STitle) 28**], [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 33**]
 [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 515**], and [**Doctor First Name 4173**] [**Doctor Last Name 4174**]. Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 4173**] [**Name (STitle) 4174**] (the staff radiologist) was
 present and supervised the entire procedure.

 TECHNIQUE: Informed consent was attempted to be obtained via telephone from
 the patient's mother. However, the patient's mother could not be reached at
 the availble phone number prior to the procedure. The right arm was prepped
 and draped in the standard sterile fashion. Using ultrasound, a patent and
 compressible right basilic vein was identified. Son[**Name (NI) 15**] guidance was used
 as no superficial veins were visible. The skin was anesthetized using 1%
 Lidocaine. Using a micropuncture set, the right basilic vein was accessed
 under son[**Name (NI) 15**] guidance. A 0.018 wire was advanced under fluoroscopic
 guidance with its tip in the lower SVC. A double lumen 5 French Vaxcel PICC
 line was measured and sized to 44 cm. Subsequently, the PICC line was advanced
 under fluoroscopic guidance over the wire with its tip in the lower SVC. The
 position of the PICC line was confirmed with a chest radiograph. The distal
 end of the PICC line was secured to the skin.

 CONTRAST: No intravenous contrast was administered.

 FINDINGS:
 Son[**Name (NI) 15**] evaluation of the right arm showed a patent and compressible right
 basilic vein. Fluoroscopic evaluation revealed the PICC line to be located
 with its tip in the lower SVC. A chest radiograph confirmed appropriate PICC
 position.

 COMPLICATIONS: No immediate complications.

 IMPRESSION: Technically successful placement of a double lumen 5 French Vaxcel
 PICC line via the right basilic vein and with tip in the lower SVC. Total PICC
 line length of 44 cm. Line is available for immediate use.



                                                             (Over)

 INDICATIONS: Clostridium Difficile colitis and malnutrition. Need for IV
 antibiotics and total parenteral nutrition.

 RADIOLOGIST:  Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 737**] [**Name (STitle) **] [**Doctor Last Name 325**] and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 6608**] [**Name (STitle) 1891**]. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **]
 [**Name (STitle) 325**], the staff radiologist was present for the whole procedure.

 MEDICATIONS:  Lidocaine 1% for local anesthesia.

 PROCEDURE/TECHNIQUE:  No clinically accessible superficial veins could be
 visualized or palpated. Therefore, after sterile draping and prepping,
 ultrasound guidance was used to perform puncture of the left basilic vein with
 a 21-Gauge needle. A 0.018 guidewire was inserted through the needle and
 advanced to the SVC. The needle was removed and exchanged for a 5 French
 dilator and sheath system. Measurements were taken and a 5 French dual lumen
 PICC line was trimmed to 47 cm in length. The dilator was removed from the
 sheath and the PICC line was advanced over the wire up to the lower portion of
 the SVC. The guidewire was removed and the sheath was peeled away. An AP chest
 x-ray was taken to confirm appropriate catheter position. The PICC was afixed
 to the skin with a Stat-Lock device and dressings.

 COMPLICATIONS: No immediately complications observed.

 FINDINGS: Initial ultrasound exam showed a patent, fully compressible, left
 basilic vein and procedure radiograph shows the catheter in appropriate
 position, with its tip at the level of the lower portion of the SVC.

 IMPRESSION: Successful placement of a 47 cm-long 5-French double lumen PICC
 line from a left basilic vein approach. The PICC is ready for immediate use.

 CT ABDOMEN WITH CONTRAST: There is bibasilar compressive atelectasis
 associated with bilateral small pleural effusions, right greater than left.
 There is deformity to the right sided ribs.  This is associated with some
 focal pleural thickening.  There is a focal soft tissue nodule in the
 subcutaneous tissues inferior to the left breast. There is probable scarring
 manifested ad thickening subjancent to the sternal sutures and contiguous with
 the pericardium. The liver, pancreas, spleen, adrenal glands, and kidneys are
 unremarkable. The gallbladder is distended and there is stranding in the fat
 immediately adjacent to the gallbladder. The stomach and duodenum appear to be
 within normal limits and there is no free intraperitoneal air or fluid, nor is
 there is free intraperitoneal oral contrast material. No lymphadenopathy is
 identified. There are no gallstones identified.

 CT PELVIS WITH CONTRAST: Opacified bowel loops are unremarkable.  There is no
 free fluid or free air in the peritoneal cavity. There is no lymphadenopathy.
 The abdominal aorta and its major branches display calcification and small
 degree of mural thrombus.  The abdominal aorta is of normal caliber.  Osseous
 structures reveal multilevel degenerative changes.

 IMPRESSION:
 1. No evidence of perforated duodenal ulcer.
 2. Minimal stranding in the inferior pericholecystic fat. Though there was no
 ultrasonographic evidence of cholecystitis, this may represent early
 cholecystitis.
 3. Right sided chest wall rib deformity with associated pleural thickening.
 4. Bilateral small pleural effusions with compressive atelectasis.
 5. Soft tissue nodule of uncertain significance as described above. Clinical
 correlation is advised.

 * [**Numeric Identifier 74**] CVL/PICC                        [**Numeric Identifier 75**] UD GUID FOR NEEDLE PLACMENT      *

 HISTORY: 71 y/o woman with a sternal wound infection requiring parental
 antibiotic therapy.

 RADIOLOGISTS: Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 178**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 179**] [**Doctor Last Name 180**]. Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 179**] [**Name (STitle) 180**], the
 attending radiologist, was present and supervised the procedure.

 TECHNIQUE: The procedure was explained to the patient and informed consent was
 obtained. The left arm was prepped and draped in the usual sterile manner.
 Ultrasound examination was performed as no accessible vein could be seen nor
 palpated. It showed a patent, fully compressible left basilic vein.
 Using ultrasound guidance, and following administration of 1% Lidocaine for
 local anesthesia, the left basilic vein was accessed using a micropuncture
 needle. A 0.018 guide wire was subsequently advanced into the superior vena
 cava under fluoroscopic guidance. The needle was then exchanged for the PICC
 introducer sheath, and a single lumen 4 French PICC, trimmed to 37 cm, was
 advanced over the wire and the tip positioned in the SVC under fluoroscopic
 guidance. The introducer sheath and guide wire were subsequently removed and
 catheter hub was afixed to the skin using the Stat-Lock system. A sterile
 dressing was applied. A chest radiograph was obtained to document catheter
 position.

 COMPLICATIONS: The patient tolerated the procedure without complications.

 FINDINGS: Ultrasound examination demonstrated patent and compressible brachial
 vein, with normal surrounding anatomy.

 Post placement chest radiograph demonstrated the catheter tip in the distal
 SVC.

 IMPRESSION: Technically successful placement of a 4 French single lumen PICC
 (37 cm long) via the left brachial vein. Catheter tip in distal SVC, confirmed
 by chest radiograph. The PICC can be used immediately.

 PICC LINE PLACMENT SCH                                          Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 26619**]
 Reason: ULCERATIVE COLITIS
 ********************************* CPT Codes ********************************
 * [**Numeric Identifier 58**] CVL/PICC                        [**Numeric Identifier 22**] UD GUID FOR NEEDLE PLACMENT      *
 ****************************************************************************
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION: Ulcerative colitis, s/p colectomy, requiring TPN and IV
 antibiotics.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  The procedure was performed by Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 2192**], [**Name5 (PTitle) **], and [**Doctor Last Name **]
 [**Doctor Last Name 325**], with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] [**Name (STitle) 325**] (staff radiologist) being present and
 supervising.

 TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS: The left upper arm was prepped and draped in the usual
 sterile fashion. Since no suitable superficial veins were visible, ultrasound
 was used for localization. The basilic vein demonstrates only partial
 compressibility in a focal region along the mid upper arm region. The vessel
 is compressible above this point and patent. After local anesthesia with 2 cc
 of 1% Lidocaine, the basilic vein was entered under ultrasonographic guidance
 with a 21 gauge needle. An 0.018 guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into
 the superior vena cava. Based on the markers on the guidewire it was
 determined that a length of 42 cm would be suitable. The PICC line was trimmed
 to length and advanced over a 4 French introducer sheath. The sheath was
 removed and the catheter was flushed. A final chest x-ray was obtained
 demonstrating the tip to be in the superior vena cava, just above the atrium.
 The line is ready for use. A StatLock was applied and the line was heplocked.

 IMPRESSION: Successful placement of a 42 cm-long, 5 French, double lumen PICC
 line from a high left basilic access vein with tip in the superior vena cava,
 ready for use.
 Incidentally noted was a focal thrombus in the left basilic vein of the mid
 upper arm. The vessel appears patent proximal to this region.

 CLINICAL INDICATION:  78 year old woman with pancreatic cancer.  Requires PICC
 line for long-term access and antibiotic therapy.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 34428**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **].  Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **], the Staff Radiologist,
 was present and supervising the entire procedure.

 PROCEDURE:  Informed written consent was obtained from the patient.  The left
 upper extremity was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  As no
 superficial veins were visible, ultrasound was utilized to identify an
 appropriate vein for cannulation.  Anesthesia was obtained with 1% lidocaine.
 The left basilic vein appeared widely patent and compressible.  Using a
 micropuncture needle, the left basilic vein was cannulated under ultrasound
 guidance and a 0.018 guide wire was advanced through the needle under
 fluoroscopic guidance into the lower SVC.  A 4-French single-lumen PICC was
 trimmed to a total length of 42 cm and was advanced over the wire into the
 lower SVC.  The line was affixed to the skin with a Stat-Lock device.  A post-
 procedure chest x-ray was obtained which demonstrates the tip of the PICC to
 be appropriate located in the lower SVC.  The patient tolerated the procedure
 well and there were no immediate complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of single-lumen 4-French 42-cm PICC via left
 basilic vein with tip in the lower SVC.  The line is ready for immediate use.

 INDICATION:  64 year old woman with end stage renal disease requiring
 permacath placement for hemodialysis.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 30992**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 29638**], with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 29638**] being present and
 supervising.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  The patient was taken to the Angiography Suite on
 [**2155-10-31**], where her right neck and chest were prepped and draped in standard
 sterile fashion.  The right internal jugular vein was patent and compressible
 by ultrasound.  After administration of subcutaneous lidocaine, the right
 internal jugular vein was accessed with a #21 gauge needle using son[**Name (NI) 211**]
 guidance. A .018 guide wire was advanced into the superior vena cava. The
 needle was exchanged for a #4 French sheath.  The .018 guide wire was
 exchanged for [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 539**] wire, which was advanced over the sheath through to the
 inferior vena cava.  The tunnel site was identified and the potential tract
 was infused with subcutaneous lidocaine.  A small incision was made with the
 scalpel at the catheter exit site in the right upper chest.  A #14.5 French 28
 cm total length, 23 cm cuff to tip dialysis catheter was attached to the
 tunneling device and advanced from the right upper chest incision through to
 the right internal jugular access site.  The right IJ was then progressively
 dilated to #14 French with the dilator set.  The dialysis catheter sheath was
 then advanced over the [**Doctor Last Name 539**] wire.  The dialysis catheter was then placed into
 the right IJ through the sheath and the sheath was peeled away.  The tip of
 the catheter was placed in the right atrium.  The neck incision was then
 closed with #4.0 Vicryl deep dermal stitches.  The catheter was secured with
 #0 silk sutures.  The catheter was flushed, demonstrating good flow, and then
 Hep- locked.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no
 immediate post procedure complications.  The patient was then taken for chest
 x-ray, which demonstrated good placement of the catheter with tip in the right
 atrium and no evidence of pneumothorax.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of #14.5 French 23 cm cuff to tip tunneled
 hemodialysis catheter through a right IJ access.  The line is ready for use.



                                                             (Over)

 There are no fractures or other suspicious lytic or sclerotic osseous lesions.

 Multiplanar reformations were obtained through the chest and upper abdomen

 IMPRESSION:
 1) Bilateral pulmonary contusions.
 2) Unusual high attenuation uniform fluid collection beneath the right
 hemidiaphragm abutting the liver. Given the setting of trauma, this is
 concerning for a hemorrhage, though of note there is no adjacent rib fracture
 and no focal abnormalities in the liver to suggest a laceration.  This
 potentially could be related to iatrogenic injury from chest tube placement.
 An ultrasound is recommended for further evaluation.
 3) Two areas of nonspecific fat stranding, one mesenteric in the left mid
 abdomen without associated bowel loop abnormalities and one in the right
 ischiorectal fossa. The mesenteric region is concerning for acute
 mesenteric injury and there could be injury to the adjacent bowel, though
 there is no evidence of perforation.  The differential diagnosis of these
 findings include contusion in the setting of trauma vs infectious or
 inflammatory process.
 4) Cardiomegaly.
 5) Simple cysts right kidney.

 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  A 27-year-old woman with endstage renal disease on hemodialysis via
 right temporary IJ dialysis catheter.  The patient needs permanent venous
 access for hemodialysis.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1035**], Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1036**] [**Name (STitle) 1037**], the attending radiologist
 present and supervising throughout the procedure.

 ANESTHESIA/MEDICAITONS:  Local anesthesia with 1% Lidocaine and intravenous
 conscious sedation with divided doses of Versed and Fentanyl were given under
 continuous monitoring.

 PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  Informed written consent was obtained.  The patient was
 brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the angiography table.
 The right neck and upper chest were prepped and draped in the usual sterile
 fashion.  2.5 cc of blood were withdrawn from dialysis port of the existing
 right internal jugular temporary dialysis catheter.  A .035 [**Last Name (un) 4540**] guide wire
 was then advanced through one of the ports and into the inferior vena cava.
 The temporary dialysis catheter was then removed over the wire and exchanged
 for a  Peel-Away sheath. Subcutaneous tunnel was then made in the anterior
 chest wall and dialysis catheter advanced throught the tunnel exiting at the
 neck incision. The catheter was then advanced through the sheath.  The sheath
 was then peeled away. The catheter was then positioned under fluoroscopy.  A
 post- procedure film was obtained which demonstrated the tip of the dialysis
 catheter to be in the right atrium. The ports were aspirated and flushed with
 ease.  Neck incision was closed with a suture. The catheter was secured to the
 skin with an 0- Prolene suture. The line is ready for immediate use.

 COMPLICATIONS:  None.

 IMPRESSION:  successful conversion from a temporary non-tunneled right IJ
 catheter to a tunneled dual-lumen dialysis catheter.  The line is ready for
 immediate use.

                                                             (Over)

 [**Hospital 4**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  62 year old man with s/p pseudomonas sepsis, needs week of antibiotics.  PICC
  RN unable to place PICC at bedside.
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Please place 2 lumen PICC.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY: 62-year-old man with status post pseudomonas sepsis, needs IV
 antibiotics. IV team unable to place PICC at bedside. Patient is here today
 for placement of a double-lumen PICC line.

 RADIOLOGISTS: Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2243**], Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 629**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 884**] attending radiologist
 present and supervised throughout the procedure.

 PROCEDURE: The right upper arm was prepped and draped in the usual sterile
 fashion. As no suitable superficial veins were visualized ultrasound was used
 for localization of a suitable vein. The right basilic vein was patent and
 compressible. Under ultrasonographic guidance through an anesthetized skin
 approach access was gained into the right basilic vein with a 21 gauge single-
 wall puncture needle. A .018 guidewire was then advanced into the superior
 vena cava. Based on the markers on the guidewire it was determined that a
 length of 34 cm would be suitable. The PICC line was trimmed to length and
 advanced over a 5 Fr introducer sheath into the superior vena cava. The sheath
 was removed. The catheter was flushed. A final chest x-ray was obtained
 demonstrating the tip of the catheter in the superior vena cava. The line is
 ready for immediate use.

 StatLock was applied and the line was heplocked.

 COMPLICATIONS: None.

 ANESTHESIA: Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine.

 IMPRESSION: Successful placement of 5 Fr 34 cm long double-lumen PICC line via
 right basilic vein, tip in the superior vena cava. The line is ready for use.

 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:

                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  61 year old female with chronic TPN requirement.  Patient requests
 single-lumen PICC line for TPN.

 PROCEDURE:  This procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 35056**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 22981**]
 [**Name (STitle) 29638**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 29638**], the staff radiologist, was present and supervising the
 entire procedure.  The right upper extremity was prepped and draped in the
 standard sterile fashion.  Since no suitable superficial vein was visible,
 ultrasound was used for localization of an appropriate vein.  The right
 basilic vein was patent and compressible.  After anesthesia with 4 cc of 1%
 lidocaine, the right basilic vein was entered under ultrasound guidance with a
 21-gauge micropuncture needle.  Hard copies were obtained before and after
 establishing an access.  A 0.018 guide wire was advanced through the access
 needle into the superior vena cava under fluoroscopic visualization. The skin
 entry site was incised with a #11 blade scalpel.  The access needle was
 exchanged over the guide wire for a 4-French micropuncture sheath with inner
 dilator.  Based on the markers on the guide wire, it was determined that a
 length of 41 cm would be appropriate.  The inner dilator was removed.  The
 catheter was advanced through the peel-away sheath over the guide wire until
 the tip was present in the superior vena cava.  The guide wire was removed.
 The peel-away sheath was removed.  The line was flushed and capped.

 FINDINGS:  A final AP chest x-ray was obtained, demonstrating the tip of the
 catheter to be present in the superior vena cava just above the right atrium.
 The line was heplocked and is ready for immediate use.

 COMPLICATIONS:  None.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of a 41-cm 4-French single-lumen PICC line
 via the right basilic vein.  The tip of the catheter is in the superior vena
 cava.  The line is ready for use.

 intraluminal filling defect is seen within the superior vena cava, bilateral

  (cannot place
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION: 74 year old with intracranial hemorrhage and poor venous access.

 PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed by Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 84460**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 30992**] with Dr.
 [**First Name (STitle) **], the attending radiologist, being present for and supervising the
 procedure. The right upper arm was prepped in sterile fashion. Since no
 suitbable superficial vein was visible, ultrasound was used for localization
 of a suitable vein. The basilic vein was patent and compressible. After local
 anesthesia with 1% lidocaine, the basilic vein was entered under
 ultrasonographic guidance with a 21 gauge needle. Procedure was slightly
 technically challenging due to patient cooperation. An .018 guide wire was
 advanced under fluoroscopy into the superior vena cava. Based on the markers
 of the guide wire, it was determined that a length of 33 cm would be
 appropriate. The catheter was trimmed to length and advanced over a 4 Fr
 introducer sheath into the superior vena cava. The sheath was then removed and
 the catheter flushed. A final chest x-ray was obtained documenting position of
 the catheter tip in the mid-SVC. A StatLock was applied, and the line was
 heplocked. The line is ready for use.

 During the procedure, the patient became hypertensive with systolic blood
 pressures of 190. 10 mg of IV hydralazine was given during the procedure.

 IMPRESSION:
 Successful placement of a 33 cm single-lumen PICC via the right basilic vein
 with its tip in the mid-SVC. The line is ready for use.

 FINDINGS:

 CTA:  There is no evidence of aortic injury, mediastinal hemorrhage, or
 pulmonary embolism.  A somewhat redundant appearance of the thoracic aorta is
 seen, which is consistent with prior aneurysm repair.  In addition, the
 abdominal aorta is aneurysmal in the suprarenal region.  It measures up to 4.7
 x 5.4 cm, with areas of mild mural thrombosis.  In addition, the aortic arch
 measures up to 5 cm in diameter on the current examination.

 CT OF THE CHEST WITH CONTRAST:  There is no axillary, mediastinal, or hilar
 lymphadenopathy.  There is dependent bibasilar opacity, predominantly relating
 to atelectasis.  Mild changes of paraseptal emphysema are also seen.

 There are several sub-cm low density foci within the right posterior lobe of
 the liver, too small to characterize.  There is no evidence of hepatic
 laceration.  The gallbladder, spleen, adrenal glands, stomach, and small bowel
 are unremarkable aside from a small to moderate hiatal hernia.  There is a 1.7
 cm low density focus along the anterior aspect of the pancreatic head.  While
 the right kidney enhances, it is extremely atrophic relative to the left.
 Multiple low density foci are seen within the left kidney, although in general
 these are too small to accurately characterize.

 CT OF THE PELVIS WITH CONTRAST:  The large bowel, bladder, and visualized
 portions of the distal ureters are unremarkable.  Multiple surgical clips are
 seen along the aorta, relating to prior aortic surgery.  There is no
 significant pelvic lymphadenopathy or free fluid.  The prostate is enlarged.
 There is an intramuscular lipoma at the left buttocks.

 neutropenic. Please remove tunneled right IJ triple-lumen catheter.

 RADIOLOGISTS PERFORMING PROCEDURE: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 994**]; Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 629**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 884**],
 the staff radiologist, present at the critical portions of the procedure.

 PROCEDURE/TECHNIQUE: The tunneled access site was prepped with Betadine.
 Suture was ligated. The tunneled site was then dissected with blunt
 dissection. The cuff was freed. There was a mild-to-moderate amount of
 bleeding at the site related to dissection in this patient with an elevated
 INR (1.6) and low platelets (25 K). This was controlled by manual pressure.
 The catheter was then removed and pressure was applied to the right neck until
 hemostasis was achieved. The tunnel access site was closed with SteriStrips
 and covered with gauge and a Tegaderm. The tip was sent for culture.

 IMPRESSION: Successful removal of a tunneled triple-lumen catheter. Tip sent
 for culture.

 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  please place a tunneled dialysis catheter- please pg [**Numeric Identifier 91677**] with questions
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  67 year old gentleman with acute renal failure requiring long-term
 dialysis access.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 78**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 551**]
 who was present and supervising throughout.  The patient's left neck and upper
 chest were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.  After infusion of
 1% lidocaine, the left internal jugular vein was accessed under
 ultrasonographic guidance with a 21-gauge needle. Hard copies of ultrasound
 images were obtained before and after establishing an access. A 0.018 wire was
 advanced into the SVC using fluoroscopic guidance. The puncture needle was
 exchanged for a 4- French catheter. Using the wire for measurement, it was
 determined that a catheter of 27 cm cuff to tip would be appropriate for use.
 A catheter was obtained and bathed in orthopedic solution.  Next, 1% lidocaine
 was infused along the designated tunnel tract from the patient's left upper
 chest to left IJ puncture site.  A small incision was made with an 11-blade
 scalpel. The catheter was then attached to the tunneling device and advanced
 from the left upper chest incision to the left IJ puncture site.  The 0.018
 wire and inner dilator of the 4-French catheter were removed and [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 16**] wire
 was advanced into the SVC using fluoroscopic guidance.
  The tract was then progressively dilated with 10- and 12-French dilators.  A
 14.5-French peel-away sheath was then advanced over the wire.  The inner
 dilator and wire were then removed and the dialysis catheter was advanced
 through the sheath using fluoroscopic guidance.  The sheath was peeled away.
 The catheter tip was positioned in the right atrium and the cuff was
 positioned just adjacent to the skin exit site.  The neck puncture site was
 then closed with 3-0 Prolene suture and the catheter was also secured with 3-0
 Prolene sutures. The line was then flushed and heplocked.  Final chest image
 demonstrated appropriated positioning of the line tip at the right atrium. The
 patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate post-
 procedure complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of 27-cm cuff-to-tip 14.5-French tunneled
 hemodialysis catheter via left IJ access with tip in right atrium.  The line
 is ready for use.




                                                             (Over)

 INDICATION:  55-year-old woman with morbid obesity with acute onset of chronic
 renal failure who needs a tunneled IJ Permacath for dialysis access.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3447**], Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3749**], and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1241**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1241**], the
 attending radiologist, was present and supervising the entire procedure. Dr.
 [**Last Name (STitle) **] d' [**Doctor Last Name **] reviewed this case.

 PROCEDURE:  After signed informed consent was obtained, the skin overlying the
 right lower neck region was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.
 Under ultrasonographic guidance, using a 21-Gauge needle, the left internal
 jugular vein was accessed and a 0.018-guidewire was advanced into the superior
 vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  The needle was then exchanged for a 4-
 French sheath and the micropuncture wire was then exchanged for a 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 112**]
 wire, which was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic
 guidance.  On the appropriate catheter length, the appropriate skin site
 overlying the left anterior chest wall was determined and a 1% lidocaine was
 used for local anesthesia.  A subcutaneous tunnel was then created with a
 blunt needle and the catheter was then advanced from the anterior chest wall
 to the lower neck incision site.  Serial dilators(8, 12 and 14Fr) were then
 used to increase the tract into the internal jugular vein and the catheter was
 then advanced through the peel-away sheath under fluoroscopic guidance.  Final
 chest x-ray documented the tip to be in the proximal right atrium.  The line
 is ready for use.  The patient tolerated the procedure well, without immediate
 complications.

 MEDICATIONS:  30 cc of 1% lidocaine, 1 cc of Versed, and 25 cc fentanyl.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of a 23-cm cuff-to-tip 14Fr angiodynamics
 tunneled dialysis catheter with the tip in the proximal right atrium, through
 the left IJ, ready to use.

 INDICATION:  Peripheral vascular disease, for IV access, needs heparin IV
 infusion.

 PROCEDURE:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3749**] and [**Doctor Last Name **], with Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **],
 the Attending Radiologist, being present and supervising.  The right upper arm
 was prepped in a sterile fashion.  Since no suitable superficial veins were
 visible, ultrasound was used for localization of a suitable vein.  The basilic
 vein was patent and compressible.  After local anesthesia with 3 cc of 1%
 lidocaine, the brachial vein was entered under ultrasonographic guidance with
 a 21-gauge needle.  Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained, documenting
 patent vein before and after establishing access.  A 0.018 guidewire was
 advanced under fluoroscopy into the superior vena cava.  Based on the markers
 on the guidewire, it was determined that a length of 40 cm would be suitable.
 The PICC line was trimmed to length and advanced over a 4-French introducer
 sheath under fluoroscopic guidance into the superior vena cava.  The sheath
 was removed. The catheter was flushed.  A final spot chest radiograph
 demonstrates the tip of the PICC in the superior vena cava, with a left IJ
 dialysis catheter terminating in the left brachiocephalic vein and a right IJ
 central venous line terminating in the SVC.  The line is ready for use.  A
 statlock was applied and heplocked.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of a 40 cm total length right brachial PICC
 line with tip in the superior vena cava, ready for use.  Note, the left arm
 was not used for PICC placement secondary to a rash.

 CT of the chest of the same day for further details regarding the lungs.

 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  62 year old woman with short gut and chronic TPN needs double lumen for abx and
  tpn.  Seen by IV team.
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  place PICC - seen by IV team and rec'd for IR placement.
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY: 63-year-old woman with short gut syndrome requiring chronic TPN. IV
 team unable to place bedside PICC.

 PHYSICIAN: [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **]. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 36098**] [**Name (STitle) 36099**].

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS: The patient was positioned supine on the angiography
 table. As no suitable superficial veins were present, the deep venous system
 of the right upper extremity was examined with ultrasound. The right brachial
 vein was found to be patent and compressible. Standard sterile prep and drape
 of the right arm. Using realtime ultrasound guidance, a 21-gauge needle was
 used to puncture the right brachial vein. Hardcopy ultrasound images pre- and
 post-puncture were obtained. A 0.018-inch guidewire was advanced through the
 needle into the superior vena cava using fluoroscopic guidance. The needle was
 exchanged for the micropuncture sheath. The PICC was cut to length based on
 the markers on the guidewire. The catheter was then advanced over the
 guidewire, through the sheath and its tip positioned at the superior vena
 cava-right atrial junction. The guidewire and sheath were removed. The
 catheter was fixed in place with a StatLock device. Both lumens of the
 catheter flushed and aspirated well, were capped and heplocked. A sterile
 transparent dressing was applied. Final limited chest radiograph confirmed
 catheter tip position at the superior vena cava-right atrial junction.

 COMPLICATIONS: No immediate complications.

 MEDICATIONS: Local anesthesia with 5 cc of 1% lidocaine.

 IMPRESSION: Successful placement of a 36 cm long, 5 French dual-lumen PICC by
 way of the right brachial vein with catheter tip at the superior vena cava-
 right atrial junction. The catheter may be used immediately.

 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 CLINICAL INFORMATION:  57-year-old man with end-stage renal disease on
 hemodialysis through temporary dialysis line in right internal jugular vein,
 needs tunneled dialysis catheter.

 PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 3714**] [**Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **].
 Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **], the attending radiologist was present and supervising throughout the
 procedure.

 After the risks and benefits were explained to the patient, written informed
 consent was obtained.  The patient was placed supine on the angiographic
 table.  The right neck, right upper chest and preexisting hemodialysis
 catheter was prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion. Pre-procedure
 timeout was performed to confirm the patient's name, procedure, and the site.
 10 cc of 1% lidocaine was applied at the right upper chest where the tunnel
 will be created.  Then a small skin incision was made approximately 10 cm away
 from the right internal jugular vein access.  A tunnel was created by using
 tunnel device.  A 20 cm hemodialysis catheter was placed through the tunnel. A
 0.035 Bentson guidewire was placed through the preexisting catheter under
 fluoroscopic guidance, with the tip in the inferior vena cava.  After the
 preexisting catheter was removed, the access was dilated by using 12- and 14-
 French dilators.  A 14-French peel-away sheath was then placed.  The
 hemodialysis catheter was then placed through the sheath.  The peel-away
 sheath was then removed.  A final film confirmed the tip of the catheter was
 located in the superior vena cava.  The lumen was flushed and the catheter was
 secured to skin with sutures.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate
 complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of a tunneled dialysis catheter through the
 right internal jugular vein with the tip in the superior vena cava.  The
 catheter is ready to use.

                                                             (Over)

 INDICATION: 57-year-old man with end-stage renal disease. Needs dialysis.

 PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 5387**] [**Name (STitle) 1374**] with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1036**]
 [**Name (STitle) 1037**], the attending physician, [**Name10 (NameIs) 6291**] and supervising. The right neck was
 prepped in a standard sterile fashion. The right internal jugular vein was
 found to be patent and compressible by ultrasound. For local anesthesia with
 1% lidocaine, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a 21-gauge
 needle under ultrasonographic guidance. A 0.018 guidewire was then advanced
 under fluoroscopic guidance into the superior vena cava. The needle was
 exchanged for an introducer sheath. The 0.018 guidewire was exchanged for a
 J-tipped 0.035 wire, which was advanced under fluoroscopic guidance into the
 IVC. The introducer sheath was exchanged for 12 and 14 French dilators used
 to dilate the access tract. The 14 French dilator was exchanged for a 14-
 French 20 cm temporary dialysis catheter, which was advanced under
 fluoroscopic guidance into the right atrium. The wire was removed. The
 catheter was flushed and capped. It was secured to the skin with 0 silk
 sutures. A final fluoroscopic chest radiograph was obtained, documenting the
 catheter tip in the right atrium. The dialysis catheter was hep-locked. It
 is ready for use.

 There were no immediate post-procedure complications.

 IMPRESSION: Successful placement of a 14-French, 20 cm temporary dialysis
 catheter via the right internal jugular vein with tip in the right atrium,
 ready for use.

 PROCEDURE:  PICC line placement.

 INDICATION:  30-year-old woman with bradycardia, needs IV access for fluids.

 RADIOLOGIST:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1037**] was performing the procedure.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique, local anesthesia, and ultrasound
 guidance, the left basilic vein was localized and punctured under direct
 ultrasound guidance.  A peel-away sheath was then placed over the wire.  A
 dual lumen PICC line was then placed over the wire through the sheath and its
 tip positioned in SVC under direct fluoroscopic guidance.  Position of the
 catheter was confirmed by chest x-ray in one view.

 The peel-away sheath and the wire were then removed.  The catheter was secured
 to the skin.  The total length of the catheter was 46 cm.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate
 complications.

 Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained before and after vascular access
 documenting vessel patency.

 IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided dual lumen
 PICC line placement via the left basilic vein with the tip in the SVC.

  floor access"
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  PICC line placement
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Congestive heart failure.  Needs IV Lasix.

 PROCEDURE:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 35132**] [**Name (STitle) 35133**] with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 22981**]
 [**Name (STitle) 29638**] being present and supervising.  The right upper arm was prepped in a
 sterile fashion.  Since no suitable superficial veins were visible, ultrasound
 was used for localization of a suitable vein.  The brachial vein was patent
 and compressible.  After local anesthesia with 2 liters of 1% lidocaine, the
 brachial vein was entered under ultrasonographic guidance with a 21-gauge
 needle.  A 0.018 guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the superior
 vena cava.  Based on the markers on the guidewire, it was determined that a
 length of 38 cm would be suitable.  The PICC line was trimmed to length and
 advanced over a 4-French introducer sheath under fluoroscopic guidance into
 the superior vena cava.  The sheath was removed.  The catheter was flushed.  A
 final chest x-ray was obtained.  The film demonstrates the tip to be in the
 superior vena cava just above the atrium.

 The line is ready for use.

 A StatLock was applied and the line was hep-locked.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of 38 cm total length single lumen PICC line
 with tip in the superior vena cava, ready for use.

 lymphadenopathy.  The heart and pericardium appear unremarkable.  The
 mediastinum has a normal size.  Examination of lung windows demonstrates
 consolidation of the right lower lobe, likely related at least partially due
 to mucous plugging.  Infection is not excluded. In addition, there is mild
 patchy opacity at the left lower lobe basilar segments posteriorly, which
 probably represents a combination of atelectasis and consolidation.

 adrenal glands, kidneys, stomach, and small bowel are unremarkable aside from
 a renal cyst in the interpolar portion of the left kidney.  A densely
 radiopaque (metallic) focus is seen between the stomach and the spleen, which
 may actually be within the stomach or the gastric wall, and is new since
 [**2180-12-16**]. Mild nonspecific fat stranding is seen within the perirenal fat and
 Gerota's fascia.  There is no significant abdominal free fluid present.  There
 is no significant abdominal lymphadenopathy.

 CT OF THE PELVIS WITH CONTRAST:  The large bowel, bladder, and visualized
 aspects of the distal ureters are unremarkable.  There is a Foley catheter
 present.  There is no significant pelvic lymphadenopathy, and minimal pelvic
 free fluid is also present.

 present.

 Examination of osseous structures does not show lytic or blastic lesions
 suspicious for malignancy.

 the right upper lobe than the left and in the left lower lobe than the right.

 glass opacity and ill-defined consolidation, predominantly in the inferior

 MEDICAL HISTORY:  62-year-old man with right-sided necrotizing pneumonia. PICC
 needed for antibiotics, bedside PICC was unsuccessful.

 PROCEDURE: Performed by [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 22919**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], physician assistant, and Drs. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 6305**] [**Name (STitle) 6306**]
 and [**Name5 (PTitle) 1240**] [**Doctor Last Name 1241**], the attending radiologist,who was present and
 supervising throughout the procedure.  Since no suitable superficial veins
 were visible, the venous system of the right upper extremity was examined with
 ultrasound. The right basilic vein was found to be patent and compressible.
 Standard sterile prep and drape of the right arm.  Local anesthesia with 5 cc
 of 1% lidocaine was administered subcutaneously.  Using real-time ultrasound
 guidance, a 21-gauge needle was advanced into the right basilic vein.  Hard
 copies of ultrasound images pre and post puncture were obtained, documenting
 vein patency. A 0.018- inch guide wire was advanced through the needle into
 the superior vena cava using fluoroscopic guidance. The needle was exchanged
 for the introducer sheath. Then, a 5-French double- lumen PICC was cut to a
 length of 38 cm based on the markers on the guide wire.  The PICC was placed
 over the wire through the sheath and the wire and sheath were removed.  Both
 lumens of the catheter flushed and aspirated well, all capped and heplocked.
 The catheter was fixed in placed with a StatLock device and a sterile
 transparent dressing was applied.  Final limited chest radiograph confirmed
 catheter tip position in the SVC.  The catheter can be used immediately. There
 are no immediate complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of a 38-cm 5-French double-lumen PICC by way
 of the right basilic vein with the tip in the SVC.  The catheter can be used
 immediately.

 HISTORY:  59 year old man with end stage renal disease on hemodialysis, history
 of L1-2 discitis and epidural phlegmon for 6 months, now with fever of unknown
 origin.

 COMPARISON:  [**2118-8-4**] MRI lumbar spine.

 INTERPRETATION:

 Whole body images of the skeleton were obtained in anterior and posterior
 projections.  Multiplanar SPECT images of the chest and abdomen were also
 obtained.  There is abnormal focal increased tracer uptake involving the right
 aspect of the L1 and L2 vertebral bodies.  Marked diffuse cardiac uptake is
 demonstrated, which could be consistent with cardiac amyloidosis.  A transplant
 kidney is demonstrated in the right lower quadrant.  The urinary bladder is
 poorly visualized, consistent with patient history of impaired renal function.
 Increased diffuse soft tissue uptake is also noted, which could reflect altered
 distribution in the setting of impaired renal function.

 IMPRESSION:
   1.  Abnormal focal osseous uptake along the right aspect of the L1 and L2
 vertebral bodies which may represent osteomyelitis, though non-specific.  This
 will be correlated to the results of the white blood cell scan when available.
   2.  Marked diffuse cardiac uptake, which could be consistent cardiac
 amyloidosis.

 glenohumeral degenerative changes with an effusion containing degenerative
 loose bodies. Further evaluation could be made with

 1.  Tunneled left internal jugular approach dual-lumen hemodialysis catheter
 placement.

 INDICATION:  Hemodialysis access required.  Prior catheter malfunction.

 OPERATORS:  [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 22921**], M.D. (fellow).

 [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1036**] [**Name8 (MD) 1037**], M.D., (supervising staff) present and supervising the entire
 procedure.

 INFORMED CONSENT:  Procedural informed consent was obtained prior to the
 procedure.

 DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:  Timeout was performed to identify the patient, the
 procedure to be performed, the site of the procedure, appropriate requisition
 and appropriate informed consent.  Once the above were verified, the patient
 was positioned in supine fashion on a special procedures table.  Left upper
 anterior chest and lower left-sided neck were prepped and draped in usual
 sterile fashion.  Patient arrived the department with pre-existent catheter at
 the left upper anterior chest wall which was also prepped and draped along in
 its exterior course.  Ultrasound was employed to visualize the left internal
 jugular vein.  The left internal jugular vein demonstrated son[**Name (NI) 110**]
 findings of a catheter located centrally within its lumen along the caudal
 course of the left internal jugular vein.  However, there was abnormal
 intraluminal echogenicity surrounding the left internal jugular vein.  The
 left internal jugular vein was also not compressible.

 Utilizing ultrasound guidance, and after the infiltration of the skin,
 uneventful one-walled venopuncture of the low left internal jugular vein was
 performed.  A 0.018-inch guidewire was advanced through the needle and
 directed under fluoroscopic visualization to the superior vena cava.  Once
 position was confirmed, the needle was removed and the 3 French/4 French
 dilator-catheter assembly of the micropuncture set was delivered over the
 guidewire and hubbed.  Thereafter, the guidewire was positioned with its tip
 at the atriocaval junction and the intravascular length of the catheter to be
 placed also determined.

 Subsequently, approximately 15 cc of 1% Xylocaine was used to infiltrate the
 skin and subcutaneous tract and for tunneling of the catheter.  Small
 dermatotomy was made in the left upper anterior chest wall at the access site
 of the catheter.  Subsequently, a 27-cm long AngioDynamics 14.5 French dual-
 lumen hemodialysis catheter was tunneled from the exit incision to the
 venopuncture site.  The latter was expanded with a #11 scalpel blade forming a
 small dermatotomy.  The pre-positioned dual-lumen hemodialysis catheter was
 then released from its retention sutures and removed uneventfully with
 hemostasis achieved promptly using digital compression at the internal jugular
 venopuncture site.  The de [**Last Name (un) 9340**] catheter tract was then serially dilated.  The
 new catheter was then delivered using modified Seldinger technique to the
 level of the cephalad right atrium.  No catheter kinks were seen along the
 course of the catheter.  Both lumens of the catheter were flushed and
 heparinized.  The catheter was sutured in place with using two, 0 silk
 retention sutures.  The catheter was then capped and heparin-locked.  The
 patient tolerated the procedure well.  Estimated blood loss was less than 10
 cc.  No complications were encountered.  Post-procedure radiograph
 demonstrates good positioning of the catheter.

 Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained before and after vascular access
 documenting vessel patency.

 MEDICATIONS:  Moderate intravenous sedoanalgesia was administered during the
 course of the procedure along with continuous monitoring of the patient.
 Please refer to nursing flowsheet for dosages.

 The wounds were then closed with occlusive dressing.  Hemostasis was achieved.

 1.  Status post placement of de [**Last Name (un) 9340**] 14.5 French AngioDynamics, 27-cm long
 dual-lumen hemodialysis catheter via left internal jugular approach.

 internal jugular approach hemodialysis catheter.

 INDICATION:  Rhabdomyolysis; renal failure.  Needs dialysis catheter for

 INFORMED CONSENT:  Procedural informed consent was obtained from the patient's
 wife via telephone.  Specifically discussed were the indications for the
 procedure as well as the attendant risks and potential complications.
 [**Name (NI) **] wife agreed to have the procedure performed and provided witnessed
 informed consent.  (The patient was unable to provide informed consent due to
 his medical condition.)

 DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:  Time out was performed to identify the patient, the
 procedure to be performed, the appropriate requisition, and appropriate
 informed consent.  Once the above were verified, the patient was positioned in

 flouroscopic guidance. Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained before and
 after documenting vessel patency. Subsequently, local anesthesia was
 administered subcutaneously and intradermally into left upper anterior chest

 STUDY:  CT-guided posterior mediastinal biopsy.

 CLINICAL HISTORY:  55-year-old man with posterior mediastinal mass, need
 tissue for diagnosis.  Please rush pathology.

 Comparison made to prior CT dated [**2155-9-4**].

 PROCEDURE:  After the procedure was explained, including risks and potential
 complications, to the patient's wife, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 102942**], acting as the patient's
 proxy, informed consent was obtained.  A timeout was performed to ensure
 accuracy.

 Patient was placed on the table in a left lateral decubitus position, the most
 satisfactory position that could be achieved on this intubated patient.
 Preprocedure scanning revealed a large posterior mediastinal mass with
 associated vertebral body destruction.  An optimal entry site was identified
 in the posterior chest, just to the right of midline.  The area was cleansed
 and draped in the usual sterile fashion and 1% lidocaine was administered
 locally. Utilizing CT guidance, an 18-gauge core biopsy needle was inserted
 into the posterior mediastinal mass, just to the right of the thoracic
 vertebral body and core biopsy specimens were obtained, placed in formalin,
 and hand delivered to the Stat Lab.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate
 complications.  Post-procedure scanning demonstrated no evidence of
 pneumothorax.

 Staff radiologist, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1886**], was present during the procedure.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful CT-guided biopsy of posterior mediastinal mass.

 INDICATION:  56-year-old man with end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis with
 right internal jugular tunneled catheter, now febrile with bacteremia.  Please
 remove tunneled catheter.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 4851**] [**Name (STitle) 2070**] and [**Doctor First Name 161**] [**Doctor Last Name 162**] [**Doctor Last Name 163**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 162**]
 [**Name (STitle) 163**], the attending radiologist, was present and supervising throughout the
 procedure.

 TECHNIQUE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was done at the bedside in the Hemodialysis
 Unit, and was performed on [**2114-11-3**] at approximately 4 PM. A preprocedure
 timeout was performed. The right chest was prepped and draped in standard
 sterile fashion. The sutures anchoring the tunneled catheter to the skin were
 cut.  The area surrounding the tunnel was infiltrated with approximately 10 cc
 of 1% lidocaine.  Using blunt dissection, the fibrous tissue surrounding the
 catheter was separated, and the catheter was removed. The tip was sent for
 culture.  Approximately 5 minutes of pressure was held over the right internal
 jugular vein.  Hemostasis was achieved. The incision site was covered with a
 sterile dressing and a Tegaderm.  There were no immediate post-procedure
 complications.  Estimated blood loss was minimal.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful bedside removal of a right internal jugular tunneled
 hemodialysis catheter on [**2114-11-3**].

 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
   56 year old man with ESRD, on dialysis, with bacteremia, no growth since 14th,
  needing access for hemodialysis, currently has a temp catheter with third port
  for antibiotics.
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  tunneled hemodialysis catheter
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  56-year-old man with end-stage renal disease on dialysis with
 bacteremia and no growth since the 14th, needing access for hemodialysis.
 Currently, has a temporary catheter requiring tunneled dialysis catheter.

 RADIOLOGITS:  Drs. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 10**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 11**] and [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 161**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 3825**].  Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 3825**], the attending
 radiologist, was present and supervising the entire procedure.

 TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS:  Informed consent was obtained.  The patient was
 placed on the angiographic table in the supine position.  The right neck and
 chest were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.  Based on
 appropriate measurements, a 23 cm, tip to cuff dual lumen dialysis catheter
 was chosen for tunnelled placement.  Approximately 10 cc of 1%
 lidocaine/bicarbonate and 10 cc of 1% lidocaine/epinephrine were used to
 create a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the right lateral supraclavicular
 region to the entry site of the temporary dialysis catheter, which entered
 into the right internal jugular vein.  Using a blunt ended tunneler, the
 tunnnel was created along the anesthetized course and the dialysis catheter
 was pulled through the tunnel, The catheter cuff was inserted approximately 2
 cm above the newly created "exit"site.

 The old incision site adjacent to the right internal jugular vein was dilated
 with a 14.5-French peel-away sheath under fluoroscopic guidance over a wire.
 The wire and dilator were then removed and the catheter extending from the
 tunnel was advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The peel-away sheath was
 then removed and the line was positioned with tip in the right atrium.  The
 neck incision was then sealed with Dermabond and the line was secured to the
 skin with 2-0 Prolene sutures. An additional suture was placed to seal the new
 incision site.  The line was flushed and heplocked.  The line is ready for
 use.

 Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of fentanyl and
 Versed throughout the total intraservice time of 60 minutes during which the
 patient's hemodynamically parameters were continuously monitored.  The patient
 tolerated the procedure well.
                                                             (Over)

 though T8, with a posterior vertical surgical staple line, and two drains

 postoperative changes including punctate foci of air in the presumed epidural

 distinct hematoma in the paravertebral area or laminectomy region is
 identified.  The posterior mediastinal mass that was previously reported is
 markedly improved, though there is still some stranding in the posterior
 mediastinum to a maximum of 21 mm in AP dimension (previously 58 mm in AP
 dimension).  A small amount of high-density material is seen in the dependent
 portion of the esophagus at this level, of uncertain clinical significance.
 There is new consolidation and atelectasis in the posterior aspects of both

 right paratracheal/precarinal lymph node measuring 7 mm in short axis
 diameter, likely reactive.

 normal in caliber, with mural calcifications but without dissection.  There is
 no evidence of pulmonary embolism in the central or proximal segmental
 pulmonary arteries.

 CLINICAL INDICATION:  42-year-old woman with cavitary lung lesion in right
 upper lobe, question of left upper lobe cavitary lesion, please evaluate.

 TECHNIQUE:  Multiple axial images were obtained after the administration of
 intravenous contrast from the thoracic inlet to the upper abdomen.  Findings
 are compared with prior portable x-ray.

 FINDINGS:  Within the right upper lobe, at the bifurcation of the anterior and
 posterior segments of the upper lobe bronchus, there is a cavitary lesion that
 measures approximately 3.5 x 2.3 cm (in long axis AP by transverse dimension,
 respectively).  Within this cavitary lesion there is a 1.4 cm soft tissue
 nodule, layering dependently.  This cavitary lesion demonstrates spiculated
 margins with retraction of the adjacent pleural surface.  No additional
 cavitary lesions seen.

 Additionally within the lung parenchyma, there are ill-defined hazy opacities
 in the left apex, in the right upper lung abutting the right major fissure,
 and in the right lower lung. There is dense consolidation of the lateral
 segment of the left lower lobe with a moderate sized overlying layering
 pleural effusion.

 Evaluation of the osseous structures demonstrate old fractures of the left
 posterior sixth through tenth ribs.  No other osseous lesions are seen.

 Evaluation of the upper abdomen demonstrate a moderate amount of ascites
 surrounding the liver and spleen.  In addition, there is a wedge-shaped low
 density area abutting the splenic capsule, compatible with a splenic infarct.
 Gallstones are incidentally noted within an unremarkable gallbladder.  The
 liver demonstrates a nodular surface and is likely cirrhotic.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Cavitary lesion at the right upper lung with soft tissue density seen
 within it.  While this may represent a mycetoma within an old benign cavity, a
 cancerous lesion cannot be excluded and correlation with direct tissue
 sampling is recommended.  No additional cavities seen.
 2.  Diffuse hazy opacities throughout the lungs may represent infection or
 hemorrhage.
 3. Splenic infarct.  Recommend echo to assess for cardiac origin of emboli.
 Findings communicated to the covering physician, [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **]. [**First Name (STitle) **], at the time of

 INDICATION:  55-year-old man with mediastinal mass.

 COMPARISONS:  Not available.

 TECHNIQUE:  Axial non-contrast CT images of the abdomen were first obtained
 followed by CT imaging of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis with intravenous
 contrast.  After a three-minute delay, additional imaging through the level of
 the kidneys only was also performed.  Sagittal and coronal reconstructions of
 the torso were also performed.

 CT OF THE CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST:  There is a large heterogeneous soft tissue
 mass in the posterior mediastinum, abutting the carina, partly encasing a
 segment of the descending aorta, and surrounding the anterior vertebral
 bodies, at the levels of T4 through T6. Much of it is relatively
 hypoattenuating, although not of fluid density. There are small foci of air
 within the mass, perhaps cavitation.

 At the upper margin of the mass, the esophageal air column disappears, and
 distally beyond the mass, the gastroesophageal junction appears normal and
 contains a small amount of air.

 There are multiple distinct enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes elsewhere in
 addition to the confluent mass. The heart, great vessels, and pericardium are
 unremarkable. There is no pericardial effusion.  A small right-sided pleural
 effusion is present, trace on the left only.  There are bibasilar opacities,
 which are most suggestive of atelectasis. There is marked emphysema
 peripherally, but no definite lung mass.

 CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITHOUT IV CONTRAST:  Evaluation of the abdomen is somewhat
 limited in that there is streak artifact due to the arms lying at the
 patient's side.  No focal liver lesions are identified.  There may be a small
 amount of sludge in an otherwise normal-appearing gallbladder, which is not
 distended.  The pancreas is atrophic.  There is some stranding in the vicinity
 of the pancreas, although not necessarily focused on the pancreas.
                                                             (Over)

 (Cont)
 Slight stranding also involves the mesenteric root and is nonspecific.  Slight
 thickening of the left pararenal fascia.

 The spleen, kidneys, and adrenal glands appear normal. The stomach, small and
 large bowel are not dilated and contrast passes through to the cecum.  Distal
 loops of small bowel do contain fluid. There is a small fat containing left-
 sided ventral hernia. There is no retroperitoneal or mesenteric
 lymphadenopathy, or free air or fluid.

 CT OF THE PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST:  There are prostate calcifications.  The
 bladder appears normal.  Sigmoid diverticulosis is noted.  There is no pelvic
 sidewall or inguinal lymphadenopathy.  There is a left-sided fat-containing
 inguinal hernia.

 BONE WINDOWS:  There are no suspicious lytic or blastic lesions. Multiple
 lower thoracic compression fractures are noted.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Large heterogeneous posterior mediastinal mass, abutting the carina from
 its posterior aspect, and involving the aorta and the spine. The mass is
 probably accessible to bronchoscopic biopsy if clinically indicated.

 The differential diagnosis is broad, in that the appearance is not entirely
 typical for any single process. It may represent a primary lung or esophageal
 cancer, or perhaps lymphoma. Infection cannot be excluded, however, although
 the bony structures appear intact, arguing again epidural abscess. An MR could
 be helpful to exclude this diagnosis if clinically indicated. Bacterial or
 tuberculous infection is also possible, the latter perhaps less likely due to
 the lack of evidence for it elsewhere.

 2.  Severe emphysema.

 3.  Bibasilar opacities, most suggestive of atelectasis.

 4.  Probable involvement of the esophagus by the mass.

 5.  Mediastinal lymphadenopathy.

 6.  Vague stranding about the mesentery and pancreatic regions.  This
 appearance is nonspecific.  It does not appear to focus distinctly on the
 pancreas, but it may be helpful to correlate with pancreatic enzymes.

 7.  Multiple lower thoracic and lumbar compression fractures.

                                                             (Over)

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 29638**] and [**Doctor Last Name **]  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 29638**], the attending radiologist,
 was present and supervising throughout.

 TECHNIQUE/PROCEDURE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right
 brachial vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using
 micropuncture set.  Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and
 immediately after establishing intravenous access. Peel-away sheath was then
 placed over a guide wire and a 37 cm double lumen PICC line was then placed
 through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the SVC under
 fluoroscopic guidance.  Position of the catheter was confirmed by fluoroscopic
 spot film of the chest.  Peel-away sheath and guide wire were removed.
 Catheter was secured to the skin, flushed, and sterile dressing applied.
 Patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided 37 cm double
 lumen PICC line placement via right brachial approach.  Tip positioned in the
 SVC, line ready for use.

 vessels are otherwise unremarkable.

 enhancing lesion is seen within the caudate lobe of the liver corresponding to

 fluid within the abdomen.  No intra-abdominal free air is detected.  The
 previously identified low-density retroperitoneal lymph node along the right
 para-aortic region at the level of the kidneys is unchanged.  Small mesenteric

 lidocaine.  Attempt was done to reposition the catheter without success.  We
 could not advance the catheter centrally. Approximately 5 cc of non-ionic IV
 contrast were injected demonstrating that the catheter was in cephalic vein.
 There was opacification of the axillary and vein and marked peripheral
 subclavian vein with complete obstruction of the subclavian vein.  We then
 decided to leave the catheter within the subclavian vein with the tip in the
 subclavian vein.  The catheter was then repositioned under fluoroscopy.  The
 tip was in the subclavian vein and was confirmed with the injection of 1 cc of
 IV contrast.  Patient tolerated the procedure well, and there were no
 complications.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Repositioning of single lumen PICC line.  The tip was left in the
 subclavian vein.
 2.  Complete occlusion of the right subclavian vein.  We were unable to
 advance the catheter centrally.

 4.  Right lower lobe segmental bronchi obstructed - consider aspiration,
 mucoid impaction.  Bronchoscopy could be considered if findings do not resolve

 fever and leukocytosis.

 suggestive of ileus.  Early or partial small-bowel obstruction cannot be
 entirely excluded but is felt not likely.
