 * [**Numeric Identifier 154**] US GUID FOR VAS. ACCESS                                                *
 ****************************************************************************
 ______________________________________________________________________________
 [**Hospital 2**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
  61 year old man with supraglottic SCC, pseudomonal PNA; also with Trach
 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Please place PICC line, pt now without access
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION FOR THE EXAM:  This is a 61-year-old man with supraglottic SCC.  IV
 access needed for medications.  The procedure was explained to the patient.  A
 timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 3001**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 166**] performed the procedure.  Dr.
 [**Last Name (STitle) 412**], the attending radiologist, was present and supervised the entire
 procedure.

 Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, various attempts to puncture the
 vein were done under direct ultrasound guidance.  Basilic vein was first
 attempted unsuccessfully due to stenosis distally confirmed after a venogram
 was obtained. Some collateral veins were also attempted unsuccessfully.  The
 cephalic vein was also punctured and after unseuccesful advancement of
 guidewire, a venogram was performed and showed distal stenosis with collateral
 veins and without visualization of the central venous system. Peelaway sheath
 was then placed over the guidewire and a 10-cm double lumen PICC line was
 placed through the peelaway sheath. Unfortunately, flushing was possible but
 aspiration was not possible from either of the lumen. The PICC line was then
 exchanged to a single lumen, again measuring 10 cm in length with its tip
 positioned in midline position of the cephalic vein using flouroscopic
 guidance. The position of the catheter was confirmed by fluoroscopic spot film
 of the chest. The peelaway sheath and guidewire were then removed. The
 catheter was secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied. The
 patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate complications.
 Hard copy ultrasound images were obtained before and after venous access
 documenting vessel patency.

 IMPRESSION:  Ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided single-lumen line
 placement via the left cephalic venous approach.  Final internal length is 10
 cm, with the tip positioned midline in cephalic vein, due to venous occlusion.
 The line is ready to use.

 INDICATION:  Pneumonia. Access for IV antibiotics.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 3743**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 3744**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1292**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1624**].  Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 1624**], the
 attending radiologist, was present and supervising for the duration of the
 procedure.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  The patient was placed supine on the angiography
 table.  A preprocedure timeout was performed to confirm the patient's identity
 and type of procedure to be performed.  Ultrasound was used to identify the
 right brachial vein which was patent and compressible.  The right arm was
 prepped and draped in the standard sterile fashion.  After injection of 2 mL
 of 1% lidocaine, a 21-gauge needle was advanced under ultrasound guidance into
 the right brachial vein.  Hard copy ultrasounds were obtained before and after
 venous access documenting patency.  A 0.018 guidewire was then advanced
 through the needle to the distal SVC.  The needle was exchanged for 4.5-French
 micropuncture sheath.  A 4-French single lumen PICC was then advanced through
 the sheath under fluoroscopic guidance into the distal SVC.  The peel-away
 sheath and wire were removed.  A final fluoroscopic image of the chest
 demonstrates the tip of the catheter to be in the distal SVC.  The patient
 tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate post-procedure
 complications.  The catheter was flushed and StatLocked in appropriate
 position.

 IMPRESSION:  Successful placement of a 4-French PICC via the right brachial
 vein with the tip in the distal SVC.  The line is ready for use.

 PICC LINE PLACEMENT

 INDICATION: IV access needed for medications and fluids.

 The procedure was explained to the patient. A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGIST: Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 23**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 7**] performed the procedure. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 7**], the
 Attending Radiologist, was present and supervised the entire procedure.

 TECHNIQUE: Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right basilic
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access. A peel-away sheath was then placed over a
 guidewire and a double lumen PICC line measuring 45 cm in length was then
 placed through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the SVC under
 fluoroscopic guidance. Position of the catheter was confirmed by a
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed. The catheter was secured
 to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate
 complications.

 IMPRESSION: Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided double lumen
 PICC line placement via the right basilic venous approach. Final internal
 length is 45 cm, with the tip positioned in SVC. The line is ready to use.

 PROCEDURE NAME:   PICC line placement.

 INDICATION FOR EXAM:  61-year-old man with SCC needs PICC for chemotherapy.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 22239**] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 44**], [**Doctor Last Name **] and [**Doctor Last Name 65**] performed the procedure. Dr.
 [**Last Name (STitle) 65**], the Attending Radiologist, was present and supervised the entire
 procedure.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right basilic
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access. A guidewire was now advanced over the right
 subclavian vein and venogram with injection of a contrast was obtained.
 Venogram demonstrated occlusion of right subclavian vein with multiple
 collateral veins.  A peel-away sheath was then placed over a guidewire and 5
 French single lumen PICC line measuring 19 cm in length was then placed
 through the peel-away sheath with its tip in the mid axillary vein under
 fluoroscopic guidance.  The position of catheter was confirmed by a
 fluoroscopic film over the chest.  The peel- away sheath and the guidewire
 were then removed.  The catheter was secured to the skin, flushed and a
 sterile dressing applied.  The patient tolerated the procedure well. There
 were no immediate complications.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Limited venogram of the right upper extremity shows complete occlusion of
 the right subclavian vein with multiple collaterals.
 2.  Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopic guided 5 French single lumen
 PICC line placement by right basilic venous approach. Final internal length is
 19 cm, with the tip positioned in right mid axillary vein. The line is ready
 to use.

                                                             (Over)

 PICC LINE PLACEMENT

 INDICATION: 85-year-old woman with pneumonia requiring antibiotics.

 The procedure was explained to the patient. A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGIST: Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1411**] and [**Doctor Last Name 155**] performed the procedure. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 155**], the
 Attending Radiologist, was present and supervised the entire procedure.

 TECHNIQUE: Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right basilic
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access. A peel-away sheath was then placed over a
 guidewire and a single-lumen PICC line measuring 37 cm in length was then
 placed through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the SVC under
 fluoroscopic guidance. Position of the catheter was confirmed by a
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed. The catheter was secured
 to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate
 complications.

 IMPRESSION: Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided 5-French
 double-lumen PICC line placement via the right basilic venous approach. Final
 internal length is 37 cm, with the tip positioned in SVC. The line is ready to
 use.

 PICC LINE PLACEMENT

 INDICATION: IV access needed for antibiotics.

 The procedure was explained to the patient. A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGIST: Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 34813**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 34688**] performed the procedure. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 34688**],
 the Attending Radiologist, was present and supervised the entire procedure.

 TECHNIQUE: Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right basilic
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access. A peel-away sheath was then placed over a
 guidewire and a single lumen PICC line measuring 43 cm in length was then
 placed through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the SVC under
 fluoroscopic guidance. Position of the catheter was confirmed by a
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed. The catheter was secured
 to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate
 complications.

 IMPRESSION: Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided single lumen
 PICC line placement via the right basilic venous approach. Final internal
 length is 43 cm, with the tip positioned in SVC. The line is ready to use.

 INDICATION:  18-year-old male with multiple gunshot wounds to the chest and
 abdomen.

 TECHNIQUE:  Trauma torso with IV contrast. Coronal and sagittal reformations.

 CT CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST:  There is a gunshot wound to the left upper chest
 with tiny metallic fragments of bullet along the expected (anterior to
 posterior) trajectory through left lung apex. Along this tract (S2:10), there
 is air and blood. There is also complete collapse of the left upper lobe. A
 chest tube has been placed and terminates at the left lung apex, very close to
 the left subclavian artery. Retraction is recommended. There is a very small
 left anteromedial pneumothorax. Subcutaneous emphysema is tracking along the
 left shoulder and chest musculature.  The right lung is unremarkable except
 for dependent atelectasis. No bony injury is apparent in the upper chest.

 The heart, pericardium, aorta, and great vessels appear unremarkable.  There
 is slight irregularity to the contour of the left subclavian artery, which
 could be related to the takeoff of a branch vessel.

 CT ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST:  The NG tube tip is coiled in the stomach. The
 liver, gallbladder, spleen, adrenal glands, kidneys, pancreas, stomach, small
 and large bowel loops appear unremarkable.  There is no free intra- abdominal
 fluid, and no evidence of vascular injury.

 PELVIS:  Pelvic ureters, bladder, small and large bowel loops are
 unremarkable. Foley catheter noted in the bladder.  There is stranding around
 the right common femoral artery, which presumably is related to a line
 placement attempt.

 OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:  There is a bullet in the spinal canal at the level of the
 L2 inferior endplate. There is a second bullet embedded within the L3 vertebra
 with associated L3 vertebral fracture. L3 fracture involves the vertebral body
 and left pedicle.  Innumerable small bullet fragments are scattered within the
 musculature of the left back, within the spinal canal and around the fracture
 site.  A third bullet is located at the lateral aspect of the left femoral
 neck.  There are several adjacent metallic bullet fragments and possible small
 bony fragments. No complete femoral neck fracture is apparent (evaluation for
 fracture is limited due to streak artifacts). There is no sizeable associated
 soft tissue hematoma.

                                                             (Over)

 REPORT:

 The examination is suboptimal for evaluation of the pulmonary parenchyma but
 within this limitation, no gross central embolism is seen.  The patient has an
 ET tube in situ, its tip in appropriate position.  An NG tube is also seen.
 There is mild concentric thickening of the entire esophagus, not previously
 appreciated on examination from three days previously and felt unlikely to be
 of much significance.  Evaluation of the lung parenchyma is limited by
 respiratory motion.  Within this limitation, there is no evidence of gross
 consolidation.  There is bibasal pleural thickening with small effusions and
 atelectasis, which has developed from [**2166-7-27**], but the degree of
 atelectasis is not thought likely to be responsible for the patient's acute
 decline.  The major airways are essentially patent to the subsegmental level,
 although again evaluation is a little limited.  A small subpleural tag is
 identified in the superior segment of the left lower lobe.  The aorta appears
 grossly normal and there is no evidence of aortic dissection.  No gross
 effusion is seen to suggest cardiac tamponade.

 CT ABDOMEN AND PELVIS:

 Examination is limited by combination of suboptimal bolus timing and beam
 hardening from the patient's arms.  No gross liver pathology is identified.
 There is moderate ascites.  There is unchanged diffuse and widespread
 peritoneal carcinomatosis.  No frank liver pathology is identified.  There is
 moderate distention of the gallbladder but no overt signs suggestive of
 cholecystitis.  No intra- or extra-hepatic biliary dilatation.  The pancreas
 appears grossly normal.  The spleen contains a focal defect along its
 superolateral aspect.  This may represent some heterogeneous perfusion because
 this is a relatively early phase of contrast.  Splenic infarction is not

 excluded.  Although there is possibly a mild increase in the amount of

 that is prevalent in this area.  The Hounsfield unit attenuation varies
 between 25 and 45 Hounsfield units, but for instance in the perihepatic and
 right paracolic area, it measures up to 40 Hounsfield units as well.  The
 adrenals appear unremarkable.  The kidneys show good uptake of contrast,
 although no gross excretion is seen.

 CT ABDOMEN AND PELVIS:

 Again peritoneal carcinomatosis with a focal area of aneurysmal bowel
 dilatation is seen.  A few foci of air are identified here in locations where
 previously there was intraluminal contrast and these are assumed to be
 intraluminal although perforation cannot be definitively excluded.  There is
 certainly no evidence of gross intraperitoneal air, however.

 CT BONES AND SOFT TISSUES:

 No suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions are seen.  There are some
 degenerative disease in the SI joints, enthesopathic change at the sartorius
 origins and there is some minimal spine degenerative disease.

 CONCLUSION:

 1.  The examination is markedly suboptimal in its timing to evaluate the
 pulmonary arteries, but no central pulmonary embolism is identified and the
 lung parenchyma is grossly clear.

 2.  No acute intrahepatic abnormality is seen.  There is background extensive
 lymphadenopathy, aneurysmal bowel dilatation and peritoneal carcinomatosis
 grossly unchanged.  While a small peripheral perfusion defect in the spleen is
 seen, this most likely reflects either a perfusion abnormality in this early
 arterial phase study or even an infarct.  While splenic rupture is considered,
 it is less likely.  There is no splenomegaly and although the Hounsfield unit
 attenuation of the perisplenic fluid is markedly limited by streak artifact,
 there is no gross difference between this and perihepatic fluid.

 PICC LINE PLACEMENT

 INDICATION:  IV access needed for access.

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGIST:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 30603**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 29638**] performed the procedure. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 29638**],
 the Attending Radiologist, was present and supervised the entire procedure.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access.  A peel-away sheath was then placed over a
 guidewire and a double-lumen PICC line measuring 42 cm in length was then
 placed through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the SVC under
 fluoroscopic guidance.  Position of the catheter was confirmed by a
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed.  The catheter was
 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate
 complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided 7-French
 double-lumen PICC line placement via the right brachial venous approach. Final
 internal length is 42 cm, with the tip positioned in SVC.  The line is ready
 to use.

 residual radiopaque fecal material within the rectal vault.  Air is noted

 slightly angulated upward and abuts the base of the superior bladder wall.  No
 pathologically enlarged pelvic sidewall or inguinal lymph nodes are noted. The
 amount of intrapelvic ascites appears slightly increased.

 CLINICAL INDICATION:  [**Age over 90 **]-year-old female with acute renal failure, requisition
 for temporary hemodialysis catheter placement.

 DIAGNOSIS:  Renal failure.

 INDICATION:  Renal failure.

 PROCEDURE:  Temporary hemodialysis catheter placement.

 PHYSICIANS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) 2143**] and [**Name5 (PTitle) 577**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 577**] was the attending
 physician who was present and supervising through the entire procedure.

 ANESTHESIA:  Local.  Anesthesia was used using a total of 10 cc of 1%
 lidocaine.

 TECHNIQUE AND FINDINGS:  After risks, benefits and alternatives of the
 proposed procedure as well as those of conscious sedation were thoroughly
 explained to the patient, informed consent was obtained. The patient was taken
 to the angiographic suite and placed in supine position.  The right neck was
 prepped and draped in usual sterile fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was
 performed.  Ultrasound guidance was used to place a micropuncture needle into
 the right internal jugular vein inferiorly.  Hard copy ultrasound images were
 obtained before and after venous access documenting vessel patency. A 0.018
 wire was then passed through the needle and into the SVC under flouroscopic
 guidance . A skin [**Doctor Last Name 724**] was made over the needle and needle was then removed. A
 micropuncture sheath was then placed over the wire. The inner introducer and
 wire were then removed.  [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 16**] wire was then passed through the sheath and
 into the IVC. Next, the sheath was removed and serial dilation of the skin and
 subcutaneous tissues was performed.  Next, an angio dynamics 15.5 French
 temporary hemodialysis catheter was placed over the wire under fluoroscopic
 imaging. The wire and inner introducer were then removed. The tip was
 positioned within the right atrium.  The catheter ports were aspirated and
 flushed.  A silk suture was used x2 to secure the catheter in place.  A
 sterile dressing was applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well without
 immediate complication.

 IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated temporary hemodialysis catheter via the right
 internal jugular vein.  The catheter is ready to use.
                                                             (Over)

 PICC LINE PLACEMENT

 INDICATION: IV access needed for difficult venous access.

 The procedure was explained to the patient. A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGIST: Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 685**] [**Name (STitle) 633**] performed the procedure.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 29638**] reviewed
 the study.

 TECHNIQUE: Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access. A peel-away sheath was then placed over a
 guidewire and a 5 French double-lumen Vaxcel PICC line measuring 44 cm in
 length was then placed through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in
 the SVC under fluoroscopic guidance. Position of the catheter was confirmed by
 a fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guide wire were then removed. The catheter was
 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate
 complications.

 IMPRESSION: Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided 5 French
 double-lumen Vaxcel PICC line placement via the right brachial venous
 approach. Final internal length is 44 cm, with the tip positioned in SVC. The
 line is ready to use.
                                                             (Over)

 CT CHEST WITHOUT CONTRAST

 REASON FOR EXAM:  83-year-old man with past medical history significant for
 hypertension, diastolic CHF, status post right total knee replacement
 complicated by septic joint, status post washout and right gastrocnemius knee
 graft, transferred to MICU overnight for hypoxia.

 TECHNIQUE:  Chest MDCT was performed without contrast using 5-mm and 1.25-mm
 axial sized thickness.  Coronal and sagittal reformations were also obtained.

 FINDINGS:  No prior study for comparison.  Correlation was made with multiple
 prior chest x-rays.

 Multifocal bilateral mostly perihilar and dependent areas of ground-glass
 opacity and septal thickening are associated with focal dense areas of
 peripheral consolidation in both upper lobes.  Small bilateral pleural
 effusions are layering.  Pericardial effusion is tiny.  Anemia is suggested by
 relative hypodensity of intracardiac blood.  Upper lobe predominant emphysema
 is present.  The right middle lobe is relatively spared from multifocal
 parenchymal opacities and some normal intervening lung is between areas of
 parenchymal abnormalities.

 Aortic valvular calcifications are mild.  Coronary artery calcifications are
 severe.  Mediastinal lymph nodes are scattered, up to 10 mm in the lower right
 paratracheal region.  Other lymph nodes are not enlarged using CT criteria.
 The main pulmonary artery is enlarged up to 3.5 cm, suggesting pulmonary
 hypertension. The trachea has a saber-sheath appearance at the thoracic inlet.
 Tiny punctate densities are in both bases, could be dystrophic calcification,
 calcified granuloma or aspirated barium.
                                                             (Over)

 PICC LINE PLACEMENT, [**2126-3-18**]

 INDICATION:  IV antibiotics.  Failed bedside PICC placement.

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  Preprocedure timeout was
 performed.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Drs. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and [**Name5 (PTitle) **] performed the procedure.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 833**],
 the attending radiologist, supervised the procedure.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access.  A peel-away sheath was then placed over the
 guide wire, and a double lumen Vaxcel PICC line measuring 42 cm in length was
 then placed through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the SVC
 under fluoroscopic guidance.  Position of the catheter was confirmed by a
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.  The peel-away sheath and guide wire were
 then removed.  The catheter was secured to the skin with 0 silk sutures,
 flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.  Patient tolerated the procedure
 well.  There were no immediate complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided double lumen
 PICC placement via the right brachial venous approach.  Final internal length
 is 42 cm, with tip positioned in the SVC.  The line is ready to use.

 INDICATION:  59-year-old man with end-stage renal disease, admitted with MSSA
 sepsis.  Patient is now status post two-day line holiday.  Please place
 tunneled hemodialysis catheter

 OPERATORS:  Dr. [**Name (NI) 453**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1414**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 307**], the attending radiologist,
 who was present throughout the entire procedure.

 PROCEDURE:  After explaining the risks, benefits and alternative management of
 the procedure, written informed consent was obtained.  The patient was brought
 to the fluoroscopic suite and placed supine on the angiographic table.  The
 right side of the neck and upper chest were prepped and draped in a usual
 sterile fashion.

 The right internal jugular vein was visualized under ultrasound and it
 appeared clotted.  Micropuncture needle under fluoroscopic and ultrasound-
 guidance was then performed of the right IJ.  A 0.018 wire was attempted to be
 placed through this clotted right internal jugular vein; however, this was not
 successful.

 Next, the right external jugular vein was imaged and also accessed with
 micropuncture needle under fluoroscopic and ultrasound guidance. A 0.018 wire
 was placed through the needle into the right external jugular vein and a
 sheath exchanged for the needle. Contrast was administered through the sheath;
 however, the tip of sheath appeared to be in a collateral vein. Contrast
 demonstrated multiple small collateral veins over the upper right chest wall
 and contrast flowing through a large collateral vein to the left side.

 It was then decided that a left-sided IJ approach should be attempted.  The
 left side of the neck and left upper chest were then prepped and draped in the
 usual sterile fashion.  The left internal jugular vein was accessed with a
 micropuncture needle under fluoroscopic and ultrasound guidance.  Contrast was
                                                             (Over)

 [**2117-9-8**] 10:17 AM
 TUNNELLED CATH PLACE SCH                                        Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 64625**]
 Reason: please place tunnelled HD cath
 Admitting Diagnosis: FOUND DOWN, S/P FALL
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 50
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 administered through the needle which showed narrowing of the long segment of
 the brachiocephalic vein.  Additional intravenous contrast was administered
 through the needle which demonstrated no filling of the SVC.  It was then
 decided that the right femoral vein should be attempted for access.

 Right groin and thigh were prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.
 The right femoral vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle under
 fluoroscopic and ultrasound guidance.  A 0.018 wire was placed through the
 needle into the femoral vein with its tip terminating in the right atrium.  A
 small incision was made over the needle and the needle was removed.  A 4.5
 French micropuncture sheath was then placed over the wire and the wire and
 inner dilator were then removed.  A wire was then placed through this sheath
 and into the right femoral vein.  A subcutaneous tunnel was created in the
 right upper thigh using local lidocaine with epinephrine and blunt dissection
 extending into the right femoral vein puncture site.  A 50-cm hemodialysis
 catheter was then placed through the tunnel following sequential dilation of
 the puncture site.  A peel-away sheath was placed into the right femoral vein
 with its tip terminating at the cavoatrial junction.  The wire and sheath were
 removed.  The catheter was then placed through the peel-away sheath with the
 tip terminating at the right cavoatrial junction.  Both ports of the catheter
 flushed and aspirated easily.  Both ports were capped.  The new tunnel site
 was secured using two non-absorbable 0 silk sutures.  Sterile dressings were
 applied.  The patient tolerated the procedure well without complications.

 Moderate sedation was provided by administering moderate sedation with 75 mcg
 of fentanyl and 0.5 mg of Versed throughout the total intraservice time of 1
 hour and 35 minutes.  The patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously
 monitored during this time.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Successful placement of tunneled right femoral vein catheter measuring 50
 cm tip-to-cuff with the hemodialysis catheter tip terminating at the junction
 of the IVC and the right atrium.  The line is ready for use.
 2.  Occluded SVC with multiple venous collaterals.  Right internal jugular
 vein occluded. Marked narrowing of a long segment of the left brachiocephalic
 vein.

 embolic CVA, as well as PFO and right heart strain on echo.

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT axial images of the chest were obtained at full expiration
 using a low-dose technique without contrast followed by a full full-dose
 technique at full inspiration after a rapid bolus of 100 mL Optiray contrast
 with multiplanar reformats.

 No previous CT pulmonary angiogram was available for comparison.

 FINDINGS:  There is a tiny subsegmental filling defect in the left lower lobe
 (3:46), consistent with a small pulmonary embolism.
 No aortic dissection or aneurysm.
 The heart is markedly enlarged and there is enlargement of the pulmonary
 artery which is associated with tortuosity of the subsegmental pulmonary
 arteries and distal tapering.  There is also evidence of right heart strain
 with bowing of the intraventricular septum into the left ventricle and
 enlargement of the right atrium and right ventricle.  A hemodialysis catheter
 passes through the right side of the heart with its tip in the distal IVC. No
 pericardial effusion.

 Left upper and lower lobe atelectasis is noted, the lungs are otherwise clear.
 Airways are widely patent to the subsegmental levels.

 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
  Please place tunnelled cath for HD
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT






 PROCEDURE:  Conversion of temporary HD line to tunneled HD line.

 HISTORY:  54-year-old woman with endstage liver disease and Hepatorenal
 syndrome, on hemodialysis with temporary catheter.  Request to convert this to
 a tunneled hemodialysis line.

 CLINICIANS:  Procedure was performed by Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 547**] [**Name (STitle) 291**], Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **],
 and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1451**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 478**].  The attending radiologist was present throughout the
 procedure.

 ANESTHESIA:  Moderate sedation was provided by administering 25 mcg of
 fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed.  During this time, the patient's hemodynamic
 parameters were continuously monitored.  Local anesthesia was also achieved
 using 1% lidocaine.

 FINDINGS:  Written, informed consent was obtained prior to the procedure, and
 a pre-procedure timeout was performed upon arrival in the angiography suite.
 The skin was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  Both ports of
 the existing temporary dialysis catheter were aspirated.  The existing HD
 catheter was measuring 17 cm.  After lidocaine infiltration, a subcutaneous
 tunnel was made over the right anterior chest wall measuring about 5 cm.  A
 new double-lumen 19 cm tip-to-cuff Angiodynamics hemodialysis catheter was
 selected and passed through the tunnel exiting at the pre-existing catheter in
 the neck.  A Glidewire was passed through the pre-existing catheter with the
 tip terminating in the IVC confirmed under fluoroscopic guidance.  The
 previous catheter was removed, and a peel-away sheath was introduced over the
 Glidewire.  A new HD catheter was introduced through the peel-away sheath and
 the sheath removed.  Final confirmation was obtained with fluoroscopy
 demonstrating the new dialysis catheter to be terminating within the right
 atrium.  The venous access site was sutured using 2-0 Vicryl stitch.  The
 dialysis catheter was secured to the chest wall using 0 Vicryl sutures.  Both
 ports of the catheter were aspirated and flushed with saline.  Dry sterile
 dressings were applied to both sites.  The patient tolerated the procedure
                                                             (Over)

 Dialysis catheter placement

 INDICATION:  Renal failure, needs dialysis.

 Details of the procedure and possible complications were explained to the
 patient's proxy and informed consent was obtained.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 65**] was performing the procedure.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the left internal
 jugular vein was localized with ultrasound and accessed with a micropuncture
 set under direct ultrasound guidance.  A micropuncture sheath was then removed
 over the wire and the tract dilated with serial dilators.  A dual-lumen
 temporary dialysis catheter was then placed over the wire with its tip
 positioned in the SVC under fluoroscopic guidance.  The wire was removed.  The
 catheter was secured to the skin and a sterile dressing applied over it.

 Position of the catheter was confirmed by chest x-ray in one view.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate
 complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided dual-lumen
 temporary dialysis catheter placement via the left internal jugular venous
 approach with the tip positioned in SVC.

 CHEST CT, [**6-7**]

 HISTORY:  Right hilar adenopathy questioned on chest radiograph.

 TECHNIQUE:  Multidetector helical scanning of the chest was performed without
 intravenous contrast [**Doctor Last Name 136**], reconstructed as contiguous 5- and 1.25-mm thick
 axial and 5-mm thick coronal and paramedian sagittal images.

 FINDINGS:  Right hilar prominence on chest radiographs is due to enlargement
 of pulmonary arteries, the right and left are each 3.2 cm, although the main
 pulmonary artery is normal caliber.  Atherosclerotic calcification is present
 in the left anterior descending and proximal circumflex branches, and at
 multiple locations in the right coronary artery and posterior descending
 branch, but not in the ascending aorta.  Moderately extensive dystrophic
 calcification is also present in the aortic valve and mitral annulus.  The
 former is more likely to be hemodynamically significant.

 There is no hilar adenopathy.  With the exception of 10-mm wide right
 paraesophageal lymph node, 2:29, mediastinal nodes are not pathologically
 enlarged and there is no pleural or pericardial abnormality. Subpleural
 opacity in the dependent portions of both lungs, particularly right lung base,
 is more readily explained by atelectasis than interstitial lung disease. There
 is no lung lesion concerning for malignancy.

 This study is not designed for subdiaphragmatic evaluation except to note the
 absence of adrenal mass.  The patient has had cholecystectomy.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  No hilar adenopathy.  Possible pulmonary arterial hypertension.
 2.  Interstitial lung disease unlikely.
 3.  Heavy atherosclerotic calcification of coronary arteries and dystrophic
 calcification of the aortic valve and mitral annulus.  Calcific aortic
 stenosis should be considered.
 4.  Ascending thoracic aorta not calcified above the annulus.

 INDICATIONS:  65-year-old man with pneumonia and fever.

 radiography from the same day.

 TECHNIQUE:  Axial CT images of the chest, abdomen and pelvis were obtained
 with oral and intravenous contrast and sagittal and coronal reformations were
 also performed.

 CT OF THE CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST:  There are multiple enlarged mediastinal
 lymph nodes, the largest being a right tracheal lymph node measuring 21 x 17
 mm in axial dimensions.  Smaller hilar lymph nodes are also present.  Some of
 these are slightly enlarged by size criteria, but most are not.  The
 adenopathy is most likely reactive. There are small bilateral pleural
 effusions.

 Multifocal consolidations are consistent with bronchopneumonia including some
 areas with complete sparing.  Early fibrotic changes including bronchiolar
 ectasia are present in the periphery of some of the consolidative opacities.

 The study was not performed as a CT angiogram, but some of the images suggest
 a filling defect in a segmental branch of the right lower lobe pulmonary
 arterial vasculature.  No other suspicious foci are demonstrated, but
 evaluation is quite limited because of superimposed opacities and faint
 opacification of arteries.

 Coronary artery and mitral valvular calcifications are present.  The patient
 is intubated. A left internal jugular central venous catheter terminates at
 the cavoatrial junction.  A PICC line terminates in the superior vena cava.

 CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST:  The gallbladder is non-distended and
 demonstrates no wall thickening.  A gradient of density within the gallbladder
 reflects sludge seen on ultrasound images of the same day.  A hemangioma
 visualized on that study probably corresponds to a 10 mm diameter hypodense
 area in the posterior right lobe of the liver.  The spleen is mildly prominent
                                                             (Over)

 PICC LINE EXCHANGE

 INDICATION: Malposition of indwelling PICC line.

 The procedure was explained to the patient. A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGIST:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3853**] performed the procedure under the supervision of Dr.
 [**Last Name (STitle) 63**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3010**].

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, a guidewire was
 advanced through the indwelling left arm PICC line, and subsequently into the
 SVC under fluoroscopic guidance.  The old PICC line was then removed and a
 peel-away sheath was then placed over the guidewire.  A new double lumen PICC
 line measuring 47 cm in length was then placed through the peel-away sheath
 with its tip positioned in the SVC under fluoroscopic guidance.  Position of
 the catheter was confirmed by a fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed.  The catheter was
 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate
 complications.

 IMPRESSION: Uncomplicated fluoroscopically guided PICC line exchange for a new
 5 French double lumen PICC line.  Final internal length is 47 cm, with the tip
 positioned in the SVC.  The line is ready to use.

 upper abdomen.

  Uncomplicated temporary hemodialysis catheter placement.

 INDICATION:  65-year-old male with renal failure.

 RADIOLOGIST:  The procedure was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 63**]. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 65**], the
 Attending Radiologist, was present and supervised the entire procedure.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  After informed consent was obtained from the patient
 explaining the risks and benefits of the procedure, the patient was placed
 supine on angiography table and the right neck was prepped and draped in
 standard sterile fashion.  A preprocedure timeout was performed.

 Using sterile technique, local anesthesia and ultrasound guidance, access was
 obtained into the right internal jugular vein.  Hard copies of ultrasound
 images were obtained before and immediately after establishing intravenous
 access.  A 0.018 guide wire was advanced through the needle into the SVC under
 fluoroscopic guidance.  The needle was then exchanged for a micropuncture
 sheath.

 The wire and the inner dilator of the sheath were removed and a 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 66**]
 wire was advanced through the sheath into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance.
 The puncture site was progressively dilated with 12 and 14 French dilators.  A
 double-lumen temporary hemodialysis catheter was advanced over the wire with
 the tip positioned within the right atrium.  The wire was removed and the
 catheter was secured to the skin with 0 silk sutures and a sterile dressing
 was applied.  Both lumens were flushed and capped.

 Final fluoroscopic image of the chest demonstrates the tip of the catheter
 located within the right atrium.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated placement of a temporary hemodialysis catheter
 measuring 15 cm in length through the right internal jugular venous approach.
 The catheter is ready to use.


                                                             (Over)

 are simple, others are complex in nature and especially one large cyst in the

 are at least three rim-calcified gallstones.

                                 FINAL REPORT


 CLINICAL INDICATION:  59-year-old male with history of bilateral upper
 extremity AV fistulas requiring PICC for IV antibiotics.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 679**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 680**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 559**] performed the procedure, D.
 [**Doctor Last Name 559**], the attending radiologist, was supervising throughout.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the
 right brachial vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a
 micropuncture set.  Multiple attempts were made to pass a guidewire through
 the vein without success.  A decision was made to attempt PICC placement on
 the left upper extremity.

 Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the left brachial vein was
 punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.  Hard
 copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access.  A peel-away sheath was then placed over a
 guide-wire and a dual-lumen PICC line measuring 41 cm in length was then
 placed through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the proximal
 SVC under fluoroscopic guidance.  Hand injection of 10 ml of contrast material
 through the PICC demonstrated a tight stenosis at the cavoatrial junction.
 Position of the catheter was confirmed by a fluoroscopic spot film of the
 chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed.  The catheter was
 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate
 complications.

                                                             (Over)

 STUDY:  Fluoroscopic and ultrasound-guided PICC line placement.

 INDICATION:  IV access needed for vancomycin intravenous.

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  A timeout was performed with two
 patient identifiers.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 389**] performed the procedure.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 65**], the attending
 radiologist, was present and supervising throughout.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right basilic
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of the ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately
 after establishing intravenous access.  A peel-away sheath was then placed
 over a guidewire and a single-lumen PICC line measuring 36 cm in length was
 then placed through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the SVC
 under fluoroscopic guidance.  Position of the catheter was confirmed by a
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.  The peel-away sheath and guidewire were
 then removed.  The catheter was secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile
 dressing applied.  The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no
 immediate post-procedural complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided single-lumen
 PICC line placement via the right basilic venous approach.  Final internal
 length is 36 cm with the tip positioned in the SVC.  The line is ready to use.

 was performed more recently on [**2188-5-8**].

 TECHNIQUE:  MDCT axial imaging was performed through the chest after
 administration of 75 mL of IV Optiray.  Multiplanar reformatted images were
 then obtained.

 CT CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST:  A right internal jugular venous catheter
 terminates in the distal SVC.  Note is made of narrowing of the right
 subclavian vein with opacification of multiple collateral veins in the upper
 right chest wall.  Aortic, aortic valvular, and coronary artery calcifications
 are as previously seen.  The pulmonary arteries are not well assessed due to
 timing of contrast bolus, therefore evaluation for pulmonary embolism is not
 possible.  Compared to CT of the chest of [**2188-4-21**], there is interval
 resolution of small pericardial effusion as well as bilateral mild- to-
 moderate pleural effusions. Since the CT of the same date, the patient had
 undergone tracheostomy, the site of which is now capped. Debris is noted
 within the upper trachea, otherwise the remaining airways appear patent.

 Again note is made of moderate upper lobe predominant emphysema.  In addition
 to dependent atelectatic changes, bilateral dependent parenchymal
 consolidations are mildly improved compared to CT chest of [**2188-4-21**].  No
 abscess is seen.  Compared to images through the lung bases on more recent CT
 abdomen/pelvis of [**2188-5-8**], consolidation in the right lung base is increased
 but is not changed in the left lung base.  These findings are consistent with
 increased opacity seen in the right lung base on recent chest radiograph,
 likely due to aspiration. Bronchiectasis in the lung bases also are likely due
 to chronic aspiration or post-inflammatory changes.

 ANESTHESIA:  Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of
 200 mcg of fentanyl and 2.5 mg of Versed throughout the total intra-service
 time of 1 hour 30 minutes, during which the patient's hemodynamic parameters
 were continuously monitored.  Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine and lidocaine
 with epinephrine.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  An informed written consent was obtained after
 explaining the procedure, benefits, alternatives and risks involved.  Patient
 was brought to angiography suite and placed supine on the imaging table.  The
 left groin was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  A
 preprocedure huddle and timeout were performed as per [**Hospital1 351**] protocol.

 Under ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance with hard copy images of ultrasound
 on file, the left common femoral vein was accessed with a micropuncture set.
 Through the micropuncture sheath, a 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 379**] wire was placed and advanced
 into right atrium.  Appropriate measurements were then obtained for the
 catheter length.  Then after instilling 1% lidocaine with epinephrine, a small
 incision was made over the anterolateral upper thigh.  From this incision, a
 50-cm tip-to-cuff tunneled hemodialysis catheter was placed and brought out at
 the venotomy site using the tunneling device.  Then after removing the
 micropuncture sheath, the soft tissue tract was dilated with serial dilators
 over the guidewire.  A peel-away sheath was placed over the guidewire.  The
 inner dilator and guidewire were removed and the catheter was placed through
 the peel-away sheath and advanced into right atrium.  The peel-away sheath was
 then removed.  Catheter secured to skin with 0 silk sutures and venotomy site
                                                             (Over)

 PICC LINE PLACEMENT

 INDICATION:  IV access needed for blood draws and IV fluids.

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGISTS:  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 547**] [**Name (STitle) 291**] performed the procedure.  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1617**] [**Name (STitle) 291**], the
 attending radiologist supervised throughout.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the left brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access.  A peel-away sheath was then placed over a
 guidewire and a single-lumen PICC line measuring 44 cm in length was then
 placed through the peel-away sheath with its tip positioned in the SVC under
 fluoroscopic guidance.  Position of the catheter was confirmed by a
 fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed.  The catheter was
 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate
 complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided 4 French
 single-lumen PICC line placement via the left brachial venous approach.  Final
 internal length is 44 cm, with the tip positioned in SVC.  The line is ready
 to use.

 have increased in size and they are now moderate with significant compressive

 small bowel loops are normal.  Contrast has yet to reach the colon, however
 the colon is less distended than on the prior exam and the previously seen
 slight thickening of the splenic flexure is no longer identified.  There is no
 ascites or lymphadenopathy.

 is a small amount of pelvic free fluid.  The sigmoid colon and rectum are
 unremarkable.

 prior exam.  Multiple minimally displaced left 3rd through 10th rib fractures
 and multiple compression deformities in the thoracic spine are again seen.  No
 suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions.

 REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:

 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 MEDICAL HISTORY:  60-year-old man with end-stage renal disease, on
 hemodialysis.  A groin HD line was pulled out a few days ago for MRSA
 bacteremia and for line holiday.  Today, the patient presents for placement of
 a new tunneled HD catheter.

 CLINICIANS:  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1090**] [**Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 713**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 714**].  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 714**], the attending
 radiologist, was present and supervising throughout.

 ANESTHESIA:  Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of
 50 mcg of fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed throughout the total intraservice time
 of 20 minutes during which the patient's hemodynamic parameters were
 continuously monitored.  Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine and 1% lidocaine
 with epinephrine.

 PROCEDURE AND FINDINGS:  An informed written consent was obtained after
 explaining the procedure, benefits, alternatives and risks involved.  The
 patient was brought to angiography suite and an ultrasound examination of the
 neck was performed prior to the procedure; it demonstrated bilateral
 occlusions of the internal jugular veins.  However, the external jugular veins
 were patent on both sides and there was evidence of multiple collateral veins
 in the neck.  A decision was made to attempt placement of an external jugular
 venous catheter on the right side.  The right side of the neck and upper chest
 were prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  Preprocedure huddle and
 timeout were performed as per [**Hospital1 351**] protocol.

 Under ultrasound guidance with hard copy images on file, access was obtained
 into a patent right external jugular vein with a micropuncture set.  However,
 the guidewire could not be advanced past the right brachiocephalic vein. Then,
 a venogram was performed by contrast injection through the micropuncture
 sheath, which demonstrated complete occlusion of the right brachiocephalic
 vein with extensive collateral formation.  Attempts to cross the obstruction
 with guidewire were unsuccessful.  Therefore, the procedure was abandoned and
 a decision was made to attempt placement of the line on the left side.  The
 micropuncture sheath was removed and hemostasis was achieved with digital
 compression.  A sterile dressing was applied.

                                                             (Over)

 [**2119-1-10**] 9:35 AM
 TUNNELED DIALYSIS LINE PLACEME                                  Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 88647**]
 Reason: Please place tunneled HD line.
 Admitting Diagnosis: SEPSIS
  Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 15
 Type of Port: None
 ______________________________________________________________________________
                                 FINAL REPORT
 (Cont)
 Next, the left side of the neck and upper chest were prepped and draped in the
 usual sterile fashion.  Access was obtained into a patent left external
 jugular vein with a micropuncture set under ultrasound guidance.  From this
 access, the guidewire could be easily advanced into the right atrium.  After
 taking appropriate measurements, the 0.035 [**Doctor Last Name 379**] wire was advanced into IVC
 under fluoroscopic control using a Kumpe catheter.  Then, attention was
 directed to tunneling the HD catheter.  A small skin incision was made over
 the left upper chest.  A 27 cm tip-to-cuff hemodialysis catheter was tunneled
 through from the left upper chest and brought out at the venotomy site.
 Because of the acute angulation at left brachiocephalic and SVC junction, the
 guidewire was exchanged for a super stiff Amplatz wire through the Kumpe
 catheter.  The soft tissue tract was then dilated over the wire.  A peel-away
 sheath was placed and the inner dilator as well as the guidewire were removed.
 The catheter was placed through the peel-away sheath and tip advanced into the
 right atrium.  The peel-away sheath was then removed.  Both ports of the
 catheter were easily aspirated and flushed.  A fluoroscopic spot chest film
 was obtained and stored digitally.  The catheter was secured to the skin with
 0 silk sutures and venotomy site closed with 4-0 Vicryl suture.  Sterile
 dressings were applied.  Patient tolerated the procedure well and there were
 no immediate complications.

 IMPRESSION:
 1.  Ultrasound examination demonstrated complete occlusion of both internal
 jugular veins with patent external jugular veins bilaterally and extensive
 collateral formation in the neck.
 2.  Attempt to place a HD catheter via right external jugular venous access
 was unsuccessful as there was complete occlusion of the right brachiocephalic
 vein which was confirmed by a venogram.
 3.  Successful ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided placement of a 27 cm
 tip-to-cuff tunneled hemodialysis catheter via left external jugular venous
 access with the tip of the catheter terminating in the right atrium.  The line
 is ready for use.

 PICC LINE PLACEMENT

 INDICATION:  IV access needed for antibiotics.

 The procedure was explained to the patient.  A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGIST:  Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 171**] [**Name (STitle) 88292**] and Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 58**] [**Name (STitle) 59**] performed the procedure.Th
 attending,Dr [**First Name (STitle) 59**], was present during the entire procedure.

 TECHNIQUE:  Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, the right brachial
 vein was punctured under direct ultrasound guidance using a micropuncture set.
 Hard copies of ultrasound images were obtained before and immediately after
 establishing intravenous access are on file.  A peel-away sheath was then
 placed over a guide wire, and a double lumen PICC line measuring 42 cm
 intravascular and 2 cm outside was then placed through the peel-away sheath
 with its tip positioned in the distal SVC under fluoroscopic guidance.
 Position of the catheter was confirmed by a fluoroscopic spot film of the
 chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guide wire were then removed.  The catheter was
 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no immediate
 complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated ultrasound and fluoroscopically guided 5 French
 double lumen PICC line placement via the right brachial venous approach. Final
 internal length is 42 cm intravascular, with the tip positioned in SVC. The
 line is ready to use.

 secured to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 PICC LINE EXCHANGE / REPOSITIONING

 INDICATION:  Malposition of indwelling PICC line, reposition existing PICC
 line.

 The procedure was explained to the patient. A timeout was performed.

 RADIOLOGIST:  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 912**] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1886**] performed the procedure. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **]
 was the attending radiologist who supervised.

 TECHNIQUE: Using sterile technique and local anesthesia, a guidewire was
 advanced through the indwelling right arm PICC line, and subsequently into the
 SVC under fluoroscopic guidance. The old PICC line was then removed and a
 peel-away sheath was then placed over the guidewire. A new single-lumen PICC
 line measuring 54 cm in length was then placed through the peel-away sheath
 with its tip positioned in the SVC under fluoroscopic guidance. Position of
 the catheter was confirmed by a fluoroscopic spot film of the chest.

 The peel-away sheath and guidewire were then removed. The catheter was secured
 to the skin, flushed, and a sterile dressing applied.

 The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate
 complications.

 IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated fluoroscopically guided PICC line exchange for a
 new 4-French single-lumen PICC line. Final internal length is 54 cm, with the
 tip positioned in the SVC. The line is ready to use.

 and curved reformats were generated in the imaging lab and reviewed.

 of the inferior division of the left middle cerebral artery.  It is well

 shift of normally midline structures.  Prominent ventricles and sulci are
 compatible with global age-related volume loss.  The basal cisterns are
 patent.  No osseous abnormality is identified.  Hypoattenuation in the
 subcortical and periventricular white matter is likely sequelae of chronic
 microvascular ischemic disease.
